Out of all the “baby’s first RPG” titles I’ve played as a child, this is the only series that’s kept me coming back. You play as a schoolboy named Lan, who sends Mega Man into the internet or local networks (dungeons) through various electronic devices where most of the meaningful gameplay happens. You go through simple isometric mazes and solve basic puzzles, pick up cash and items, and get hounded by random encounters. There’s a lot of fetch quests, repetition and archaic RPG design that may turn off a lot of people. None of that matters because Battle Network has peak Action RPG combat. 

Combat is a combination of card game and action game where you dodge enemy attacks by moving on a 3x3 grid, while the enemies do the same on another 3x3 grid. You can pick at enemies with your infinite-use Mega Buster but most of your damage will come from using cards (battlechips) with various uses, from simple projectiles to functions like icing the entire stage. You start off being able to draw so many chips and every few seconds you’re able to pause the game to draw some more. Pausing constantly in an action game is usually a bad thing, but here it’s good as it lets you formulate a strategy in the chaos. Enemies have predicable attack patterns, you may think “This guy is gonna jump around twice more and then stop to shoot me, I’ll use this air chip to push him into same row as his friend, and then take them both out at once with this bomb chip!”, things may go awry and then you’ll have to improvise a new plan. As with any card game, your starting hand is randomly selected from the cards you put in your deck, this keeps encounters fresh since you’ll be readjusting on how to best deal with the enemy with whatever you’re dealt. Good deckbuilding is making sure you will never end up with a hand that’s unusable. Skillful play is directly rewarded, your combat speed/efficacy is graded and gives you better rewards at the end of combat the better you do, giving you either more money or chips. You don’t really level up traditionally, but cash is usually handy and chips are you main source of power. Even trash chips are welcome as you can use them to roll on a chip trader, which can give you basically any chip from more garbage to absurdly broken things you would otherwise need to S rank endgame level bosses for. In short, combat is fast, easy-to-understand and has a surprising amount of depth and customization for how simple it looks. Despite the problems these games have with content and balance, I would say the skeleton of this gameplay is basically perfect, and the best successor to Battle Network has cloned these fundamentals 1-to-1. Here’s a rundown of the games themselves.

Battle Network 1: The start of it all. The combat isn’t as good as its sequels but it still has the core of what makes BN combat fun. Unfortunately the game is very rough in typical first-game fashion. It’s short and the mechanics aren’t well developed. The encounter rate is insane. The overworld is a barely-navigable mess with a single tileset and it has one of the worst dungeons ever made. I wouldn’t say you should skip the game without trying it, but if you start getting frustrated with fumbling around in the dark there’s not much shame in going ahead to a much better game.

Battle Network 2: The typical Mega Man sequel where the devs nail it. The game is longer and much more polished. There’s more than one visual theme in the overworld, so it’s possible to navigate now. The combat/deckbuilding mechanics are much better and there’s a new style system where the game buffs you based on your playstyle. For example if you draw a lot of chips you’ll get the Custom style which lets you start a fight with more potential chips to draw, if you use the buster a lot you’ll get the Guts style which buffs the buster. Unfortunately it can be grindy, if you somehow end up with a style you don’t like you’ll have to fight 200+ battles to get another one. You can level up styles by fighting battles, but all it does is strengthen your charge shot. Styles are still a positive addition, giving a lot of customization and depth. BN2 also starts the series’ tendency towards surprisingly extensive post-game content. There’s a lot of collecting/grinding involved if you want to do all of it, but entire areas, sidequests and unique bosses for expert players are only found after the credits roll. This is welcome, especially when a lot of RPGs are still content with giving you one superboss, if anything at all. One problem that will stick with the series is there’s a decent amount of padding added, BN2 adds a lot of mundane fetch quests going back and forth across previously explored internet areas. One such section is atrociously bad, but for the others I’m not gonna complain too much when the game asks me to engage in more combat. All-in-all this is a great game and a big improvement over its predecessor.

Battle Network 3: BN3 takes BN2 and expands it even more. There’s a greater variety of chips, enemies and bosses. There’s a new “NaviCust” system where you place blocks (programs) down a grid to give Mega Man various benefits like a stronger buster or the ability to survive a fatal hit with 1 HP. It’s basically inventory Tetris but with your stats and I wish more games had something like it. They weren’t too sure how to implement it here though, as several parts of the internet/main quest require equipping a program to progress, forcing you to constantly swap out programs or gimp yourself by leaving on something that’s otherwise useless. Styles are back and leveling them up gives you programs for the NaviCust, so you’re encouraged to branch out instead of just sticking with one you like. BN3 is the longest in the series, but there’s also even more padding than 2, which can be grating. On the other hand, BN3 also has an insane amount of postgame content, some say it’s the second half of the game and they’re probably right. If the game were made today content of this size would be paid DLC but it’s just included in the game already, accessible only to the most dedicated players. Times have certainly changed. Unfortunately what has been consistent is Capcom’s love of scummy business practices, this is the first game in the series to have two versions ala Pokemon. Thankfully its not too bad and they’re both in Vol 1. There’s a few chips and one style exclusive to each version, Blue is a bit more favorable due to having an extra boss but otherwise you can pick your favorite color between the two. Despite its problems, BN3 is excellent and one of the best games in the GBA’s library.

I didn’t mention the story, it doesn’t matter at all. It’s episodic children's anime stuff about as meaningful as a classic Mega Man plot, but with more yelling about friendship and hearts. It’s kinda fun thinking about how insane this world and its events are. The first dungeon in the series is a program forcing an oven to spit fire. It’s weirdly prophetic as well, considering how many of the scenarios are about bad guys hacking devices that shouldn’t have been made with any internet access to begin with. But if you want Deus Ex you should look elsewhere.

For what the collection adds, you get Mega Man talking to you on the game select menu, far from necessary but it’s nice. There’s typical extras like art galleries, trophies and a music player. The music is surprisingly good for GBA games, it’s like the system’s audio capabilities were made to make bubbly techno sound good and nothing else. You can import Japanese event exclusive chips which have been basically inaccessible by official means up until now. There’s also online PVP and chip trading to help you collect them all, definitely beats a link cable.

So for Volume 1 you get a rough prototype of a game and two great games. There’s a lot of stuff here, especially if you do post game content. I’d say it’s worth it even at its base price if you value excellent combat above all else.

After just doing the tutorial and assembling a single guitar, I wasn't sure if the game play loop would be enjoyable enough to warrant the 20 or so minutes it takes to complete the building process. But I gave it one more go without the tutorial, turning off the in-game music and putting on an Bomb the Music Industry! album I haven't heard before (SCRAMBLES), and found how the games starts to shine.

The act of juggling around multiple orders at a time makes the game play much more interactive. While a majority of the parts are pre-chosen by the customer, the user still gets to make some active decisions based on what's in stock, the desired quality and/or cost of the build, and a bit of creative freedom like the material of the body or the shape of the fret board markers. All the while, I found myself passively appreciating and critiquing the customer's choices as the guitar's body and colors start to form, looking at each one as though it was a real guitar. And since the game play wasn't too demanding, I was able to fully digest the music in the background, giving me a new way to activity listen to music outside of driving.

While there is still much to be explored that is locked in the prologue (working on new instruments, market/stock management, expanding/upgrading the workshop, mastering material proficiency, brand globalization, etc.) there are still plenty of areas in the game play that leaves some desires (such as not being able to wire/solder the electronics, no bridge adjustments, and the lack of responsiveness when strumming while playing the instrument). But overall the game seems very promising and is worth giving a shot by any music fan. Looking forward to what is added in the full release.

P.S. (Highly recommend trying it with your favorite music in the background. While I enjoyed the in-game music, substituting it transcends the experience.)
Well developed demo with a huge amount of potential. Definitely going to be first in line on launch day!

Another title published by Puppet Combo under their Torture Star Video branch, with this one starring you as a movie rental store employee being forced to go into work on your day off, until said day starts becoming a little out of the norm with the inevitable arrival of a crazed masked murderer.

I think a good comparison for this one would be Bloodwash, another Torture Star Video published title, as opposed to something like Deadly Night (which is in the same vein as Stay Out of the House.). I think the only time things I could complain about are the fact the first two chapters just made me miss Blockbuster, and with another Puppet Combo/Torture Star Video release, it leaves me wanting them to get official cosmetics into Dead by Daylight more.

Rewind or Die is pretty much the standard affair for these VHS styled horror games. Protagonist goes to job/does mundane task but bad things are going on in the area, well doing said task/job spooky stuff happens and eventually the killer comes and you have to escape/confront said killer. 

It doesn't really tread any new ground, but I wouldn't say it is a bad game. Puzzles are enjoyable, I loved the chase music (it made the game feel like a cheesy b-movie which was a fun move), and the environments look nice. The biggest downside for me is that the game just isn't that scary. The atmosphere falls flat for me. I wasn't at all unsettled, just jump scared a few times. 

I had an enjoyable two hours, but I wouldn't recommend this one over games like Bloodwash or Murder House that  handled the formula better in my opinion. It's a solid 7/10 game for me.

This game is very fun, sure its just run around and loot + Shoot now, but its obvious there is love put into this game.

I feel like most people have the issue where it feels repetitive but that's where games like this are the strongest. The Dev put it under the About section saying gameplay is subject to change and be more based on base building survival mixed with the elements already there. I played Solo and honestly it's still fun, but this game is also my cup of tea.

I can't wait to see how the game does in terms of development and moving forward because in my opinion it handles the wave survival genre really well.

Pros:
-Enemies have a chance to drop loot
-Bosses feel like a proper challenge especially where they are spawned at
-Loadouts before game starting makes it worth going for the bosses for unlocks
-Melee combat feels good when needing to conserve ammo and doesn't feel like a last option
-Different item types to let you build different ways as you explore
-The map telling you which houses have weapons is a nice touch to let you know what a starting goal is after spawning

Cons:
-Items feel scarce sometimes with having empty houses especially later in the game when healing and energy is really needed
-Stamina runs out pretty fast with it being drained by Sprinting,Rolling, and Jumping
-The area's all look the same so getting lost is very easy (Opening the map fixes this issue easily, but for some who have a hard time flicking between having map open and closed it can be challenging for some but not a big Con honestly)

I feel like as this game develops it will become a hit for friends to just hop on to have a good time and chill. and that overall is what makes it a good game in my opinion.

For an alpha the bones are there but they aren't giving me much confidence. I imagine that this will improve when the Beta comes out, this however is too early days to get any quality content from and maybe should of been left out and started from Beta instead. Wishing well for future developments.

I'm hoping for more events and quests and hopefully a bit of combat at some point. There are a few minor things that I hope get worked out too with pathing issues and a few items of inconvenience- like being able to replace gravel roads with cobblestone without destroying them first would be nice and save time. I still highly recommend this game if you want a cozy, fun, city builder to play and look forward to the update.

Hunt the night is a top down souls-like that, especially in regards to the lore and environmental storytelling, delivers an amazing experience. The music and art of this game are exceptional, and the exploration is very satisfying, especially when any part of the environment could be a key to understanding a key piece of lore.

The game does an AMAZING job of encouraging the player to engage in the lore, with many puzzles being tied directly to it. I dont think they are so complicated that you need a full understanding of the lore or anything close to it, but by asking the player to even lightly interact with the lore to progress, it gives a base level understanding of the world and story being told even to a player who may otherwise not be reading things or thinking about it.

Now, I know not everyone is into the storytelling side of things, and as far as game play goes, I have been thoroughly enjoying learning the combat. For me, the combat is secondary to what really makes this game so amazing, but it is still fun. The boss fights have been challenging but not frustrating so far, which I always appreciate.

Hunt the Night is absolutely worth your time, and if they add full steamdeck support with cloud saving, it will take it to the next level.

I like this game, you can tell it'll be good when it's finished.  At the moment there isn't any conflict but you can build walls and guard towers so there will be at some point.  You kind of run out of stuff to do at 20 mins in though

Just as it says on the roadmap, the early access version seems to lay solid foundation for the future. At the moment you can finish all the available quests in one or two evenings and then focus on expanding your territory.

Impressive for such an incredibly small team. Cute, relaxing, though sometimes perplexing game at this stage. Lacks content, but it's clearly in the works. Balancing resources, people, money, and employment can be a challenge at times. 

I thought peasants would leave if they were homeless for too long since that's what the writing implied, but they just straight up starved to death without a home and dropped dead at the 'plaza.' So I unintentionally euthanized a third of my people when trying to replace peasants with common folk from lack of space. Then my common folk also began starving too- I'm wondering if "They're more demanding" means they consume more food? I got confused there.

Anyhow, after mass murdering dozens of people I made a new save and it's going great...

Coal makers feel highly inefficient with little employment, slow production, low desirability, and high upkeep after so many of them- only for the game to not even react if my people don't have coal to heat their homes in the winter. So I opted to just let them freeze since it's easy to ignore with no consequence. Coal makers are definitely my least favorite building in the game.

I hope the next neighboring ruler is a guy who looks... a touch more handsome than Giovanni... his character design is creative, funny, and unique- but I'm -not- that desperate. Oh dear.

I'd love a preview of what royalty/nobility points could unlock for me in the future. For now, I didn't care too much- though the pop up quests not having an option to decline without penalty (especially early on in the game) stressed me out. It felt like time was rolling the dice as to whether I was punished or punished less harshly, especially when struggling with money and food already. Hell, an option to turn those off for a more relaxing experience would be great too. It reminded me of sim city's random destruction events.

My least important peeve was the cake-like fog around the border edge of the map. Kinda kills my immersion when I view a map and the visual horizon from my camera doesn't match up, but I also have no idea how this could be fixed and I can see why the developers picked such a solution for now at least.

This game is cute and fun though, I'd probably play it again alongside Dorfromantik whenever I want something less intense than the usual.
All it's missing is [spoiler] Shrek [/spoiler]

Alright look these are good games. Great games even. But for $60 (and I feel spoiled saying this cause I know it's only $10 a game or $6 if you include all versions) I expected more. This is literally the bare minimum and if this version didn't give you online battle and trading abilities the emulated versions would not only serve the same purpose for free but would actually be better. You would be able to have a black border that doesn't ruin oled screens, remap buttons, toggle run, fast forward, and save state for all the shitty stupid not fun parts. This version doesn't fix any of the old translation errors which is infuriating. "Go left to get to the netdealer. Turn right at the square and follow the big path." Apparently that means the netdealer is on the left and the square is to the right. Nonsensical. The left bumper "hint" is still useless garbage. Hmm I'm doing a quest so I can take the exam. What was the quest again or where am I supposed to go? Lemme ask for a hint. The hint just says lets finish the quest so we can take the exam. Like you seriously couldn't go back through and give real hints? So then you either look up a guide or jack out and run halfway across town to see what the quest was or where you are supposed to go. Can't set spoken and written languages separately. The graphics suck. I know I get it it's an old game but they said they remade it. You really couldn't upscale at all? You literally have to make the window smaller than your screen for it to look decent. Which leaves you with the border which can't be made plain black and is super ugly. Even if you play at full size there is still side borders because they didn't bother to make the game wide screen. There is some filter that is supposed to make it look better but it looks worse. And on top of all this stupid other bullshit they put denuvo on it which makes no sense because the only reason not to emulate the game is for the online capabilities. If somebody pirated this version it wouldn't have online and at that point it would just be worse than an emulator. There is literally no reason to pirate this version and they slap denuvo on it anyway and now people with steam decks and laptops can't play on the go without an internet connection. Idk man like I'm keeping the game and going to play because I don't have anything else I wanna play right now and I do want to trade and battle online and AGAIN THESE ARE REALLY FUN GAMES but this is just such a lazy minimal port that I can't recommend it for $60. Which again I feel bad saying knowing it's $6 a game but shit man they could have at least tried instead of coasting on the fact that online play would make this the only option. Very disappointing overall. If you aren't going to play online just get an emulator. There apparently is some previously japanese exclusive content in this version that wouldn't be in the emulated one but idk if that alone is worth $60 if you aren't going to play online. It's just extremely frustrating to put off replaying some of these for this release only to find out you get a better experience for free on emulators.

There comes a time in every man's life when he needs to take a look at himself in the mirror and wonder how exactly he reached such a place.
You have to truly ponder what decisions you have made along the way that brought you to the place of your final reckoning.

It is still unclear, even to me, why I purchased Is It Wrong to Repay the Debt in a Dungeon?.
There isn't anything wrong with it, with those nudity scenes throughout it's perfectly stellar. But when you look at it as a choice, you realize just how flawed you and the rest of humanity is.

What drove me to purchase such a game? What part of my soul felt so empty that I thought a virtual girl could fill it?
When I look into the boundless depths of my own loneliness I see a pool of reflection. My face isn't there, there is no face. There are only tears in that pool, tears of shame and loss and confusion.

If it were up to me again I know I would purchase it in a heartbeat, I know I would load it up and skip through the countless window prompts so I can have a single morsel of pornographic images which are readily available online.
Yet, despite the abundance of naked virtual women waiting in the digital sphere, I still chose to purchase this game and devote hours of my life to it. That time will never return to me, it is lost just like my soul and just like the time I fear I may never find it again.

There is something broken within me, something that desires sensation beyond my reach, something that whimpers every single night with the knowledge that there is no true Princess, it is a merely an illusion.
In my pursuit to find meaning in this long life, I sought the colorful lights and sounds of a world that only exists in a pop up window on my computer.

I am unsure what the moral of this review is, I am unsure about my place within the universe, all I know is that no amount of virtual girls can cure the vast rot that has overtaken me.

I am sorry I have to disagree with a lot of my fellow Pinball Players, I too have played Pinball FX on many platforms, bought the games as well on many platforms. This time it is different and this New version Rocks in it's own unique way. There obviously has been a lot of work put into this, the interface is excellent, the table choices are vast with a wide variety of fun to be had. The game play for me was lag free and I even compliment them on making a day of trial fun a great way to present this new and exciting Pinball FX experience. I am like everyone, no one wants to pay more money for tables you may already have, so don't just buy games you may already have on other Zen products, buy the games that are new or fresh to you. I agree that a few maybe are over priced, in that case we wait for a sale. But overall, Pinball FX get's the Geo Pin Pinball seal of approval, I have played Pinball, video games as long as anyone in existence, so do not try to out elite me. This package will get my dollars, I will just be very calculating what and when I buy. I say great job to Zen for creating some excitement back on Steam, for me it has become boring, until the release of this new Pinball package, keep up the great work and keep the tables coming Zen!

Part of what I enjoyed in FX3 was competition and I made friends through it.

Wait until bugs are fixed and maybe a better discount is offered to FX3 customers.

After a bumpy birth, Pinball FX's debut on steam is off to a strong start. The Williams tables especially are of high quality. Great physics, great graphics, and integrated cabinet mode. They play exceedingly well, and I look forward to future releases. There are more improvements to be made, but it's off to a great start.

Initially a 1-year exclusive on another platform, tables were only purchasable in-game with tickets, The benefit of this was ostensibly cross-platform play, but the downside is that players would have been locked into the developers eco-system. 

Over the course of a year, and a lot of negative feedback, the developer changed their approach to allow direct-DLC purchases after it debuted on steam as they had on previous iterations of their pinball games. Players that purchased tables on other platforms were given a 1-time form to fill out to transfer tables to a single platform of their choice. 

Likewise, steam will detect if you own a table on Pinball FX3 and give users a 50% off credit to purchase the license for Pinball FX.

I was in love with this game from the moment I loaded the demo. It's relaxing, easy to play and rewarding. Building is satisfying. Resource management doesn't grind to a halt in a split second like other games I've played. The world feels rich and vibrant. Having a hero you send off for encounters is brilliant - as are the choices you can make during these.
The only negative things I can think of are likely just limitations of early access and some of these have already been changed in a patch. I'd love to see the ability to relocate buildings added - sometimes I've miscalculated my space and don't realise until much later. I'm sure we'll also see more courting options and combinations in the weeks to come.
Overall this is an overwhelmingly adorable, satisfyingly cozy game and I cannot get enough of it.
Welp, there I go, wasting my entire life on a video game again.

Even for early access, this is pretty bare-bones for a city builder. There's not much more content outside what you see in the demo.

It is very cute though, with stylistic decisions I can get behind. I also like how they're making some of the structures less static than just placing squares and rectangles. They do need to extend this to more buildings than just housing and stockpiles though.

The biggest problem right now is that the "fable" part of the name is fairly cosmetic at this point. We are dealing with pigs with wings, there's a princess, and a talking tree somewhere on the map. Otherwise, it's just a regular city builder like you've played before. I've built the well for my houses in so many games. I've built the tavern to make my people happy countless times before. I've built the wheat farms for my windmills for my bakeries every year since playing Settlers II back on windows 98. Let me build and set up actual fable stuff. What about needing to build mushroom huts for gnome citizens, and then I can employ them to spin straw into gold? Or trying to host a coven of wicked witches but trying to put together a sufficiently spooky swamp in time?

Ultimately, this game has potential, but in the same way that a lump of rainbow playdoh has potential. It's kind of nothing right now except, appropriately, castles in the sky.
Such a cute art style and a perfect city builder to sink some time into just watching your people thrive! Cant wait to see where it keeps going!

Really fun XCOM-like game. The characters are meaningfully different, and the enemies difficult but not too overwhelming. Only complaint is unlocks are linked to achievements, which are difficult to set up.

One thing I love about the UAN overarching narrative is that it never loses the horror genre to the fact that the protagonist is becoming more acquainted with the monsters he fights. Even though Nick fights monsters on the regular, you never interact with it, never see it, and Nick has stayed the broken shell of a fearful teenager that he was when the proverbial fecal matter hit the metaphorical fan in the first game. He remains a protagonist that is just trying to survive (when he isn't self-sabotaging) and that makes the series retain it's horror feel where most series would have long since lost it.
Have you cried yet? You should be.

If you're looking for a truly unique and surreal gaming experience, look no further than this game. The game takes you on a psychological journey that feels like a dream-like trip. The art style is incredibly unique, perfectly capturing the bizarre landscapes that our minds create when we close our eyes, and when shadows, intrusive thoughts, and apparitions blend with our own fears and anxieties.

The protagonist's journey is shrouded in mystery and intrigue, with the game's use of psychological and atmospheric horror being particularly effective.

If you're still on the fence about buying this game, let me assure you that it's absolutely worth the ticket. The game is a true work of art, and it's clear that the developers put a lot of heart and soul into bringing this surreal world to life. Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants to experience a truly unique and captivating journey through the human psyche.

This game is EXTREMELY good, if you liked Classic Siege, this is an absolute treat. The guns feel very satisfying, the reloads and grabbing are very slightly confusing, but just take some getting used to, and overall, the level of interactivity is moderately low, but just enough that it keeps the balance of the game in tact. 

Eco/weapons feel very similar to Valorant or CSGO, with the tiers for purchasing weapons, weapon classifications, and damage feeling more similar to Valorant. If you understand some of the buys there, things are very uncomplicated. There's good weapon variety, and I actually think that the reload system (you simply drop the mag and put a new one in, then wait for the weapon to be ready) evens out the skill gap present in reloading VR guns. I'm mixed on this because I am very fast at reloading guns, but it also allows more people to engage with the game elements in a deeper way if they aren't muddled down in the moment to moment reloads. 

The actual gameplay loop is extremely similar to when Siege first came out, with a slight mix of CS style throwables for good measure. Breaking down windows, clearing hallways, creating entries, it's all here aside from fully destroy-able walls. There are set breaching spots, but as I'm sure the designers of siege learned, that specific breach spots are probably for the best in terms of balance. Soft walls are a nightmare to balance around, and this game reaches a happy medium. 

The gadgets are all moderately futuristic, and with a very polished, cohesive tutorial, it all feels quite intuitive. "Ease of use" is a very nice way to put how most of the gadgets feel, aside from maybe grenades being that they have a higher skill ceiling inherently. 

The gunplay feels great, the guns all sound very chunky and powerful, even the default pistol sounds adequately loud. Big pluses all around. 

Movement is surprisingly smooth, with the ever looming threat of VR sickness, it's hard to find a game that sets this level of smooth movement, and does it in a way that (to me) feels extremely good. If you feel comfortable playing Pavlov, you're gonna be just fine here more than likely. 

That being said, Pavlov is a much more community focused game, whereas this game feels nearly competitive ready. The ability to see people only when teammates see them after death, the limitations on crouching, the ease of use, and the balance of weapons and gadgets, all of these are typically afterthoughts from developers after creating "just another VR shooter" but this game is one of the most polished, thorough experiences I've had so far in VR. This is, if you're into shooters, probably a must buy. Sure, there are lots of Quest players with dying headsets, and the audience might be a bit young, but that certainly doesn't take away from how great this game plays and feels. 

For the first time in a while, I got out of VR after getting a server disconnection, and as I write this I'm like, "dang, I want to play more" which hasn't happened in a very long time in VR.

Zen messed up with this "new" Pinball FX. Every decision made in the process of making this game was met with push back by the fans, and usually id say "well give that feature a chance, maybe it'll be good" but every 'feature' added felt like another step in alienating the fans from every prior version up to this point. I finally tried this out today when I found out it hit steam earlier this week, the problems that were present in the beta edition are still there. Physics break and even cause some tables to become unplayable, such as Funhouse which won't let the ball go anywhere but down center, no matter how much you thrash you flippers. The Visuals look the same except they now have blur and slowdown from a system that had neither of those issues in the prior release which was on higher settings too as opposed to medium on this current one. In all honesty just stay with FX3 if you want playable, if not enjoyable Pinball, eventually current FX may become the new Pinball Arcade in regards to dying fast.

I refuse to rebuy copy/pasted tables from FX3 or pay a subscription for content I already bought.

Great game, my current annoyances/feedback:

* Unable to turn down/off audio of in-game announcer (the lady that yells about objectives).

* Recommend to hire a community manager or assign someone internally that is fluent in English to deliver better communication around the game to the non-China playerbase.

* Hopes of longer/larger/PvE/PvPvE game modes. Right now, running a short match with a small player count, going back to main menu, another quick game, main menu, quick game, main menu, it just isn't great for long-term replayability. I played 2 hours and felt like I went through 20 matches which wore me out.

* Accessibility options that may help with character rotation in space. This is one of those inevitable games where you'll feel the vertigo/motion sickness. Something that would allow forcing a vertical map so your character is unable to rotate with feet always at what would be considered the ground. I understand this could take away from immersion or the whole reason you're playing a game in space, but it's also not unreasonable if it can decrease player count because of uncontrollable dizziness. I also don't see the 'well if you can't flip around you're at advantage' - on the contrary, I would think players that can would have the advantage.

* You've spent years developing the most realistic FPS in space - why bog it down with cartoony/comedy skins and attachments and break the immersion? I'm sure the answer is that 'it sells', but this deserved to be mentioned. Imagine if the cosmetics and skins were military-esque or futuristic, as they should be? It builds to the tactical aspect of space combat when seeing other players looking the role. Just a thought.

You can try and deal with the vermin as they approach - but be warned that you will be overrun in a matter of rounds if they get out of hand.

During the turn based phase you can potentially find supplies that will help you once you reach a shelter. Once there you can create items, upgrade weapons and heal your soldiers to fight another day. You also get a little robot companion which is nice! DO NOT LET THEM DIE FOR THE LOVE OF GOD!

If you enjoy turn based games and getting smashed into the ground constantly, give this game a go! While sometimes unforgiving, it is a very, very good game!

I bought this because I really enjoyed Dungeon of Nehauleuk published by Dear Villagers.

Surprisingly good city builder sim for early access with a lot of the humour shown in DoN. The real enjoyment for me will come when the RPG elements are built out into a proper story line. I get super bored with city building for city building sake so looking forward to the development releases.

7/10

- A fun gameplay loop that becomes repetitive after 4-5 scenarios. 
- Almost every scenario is moving left to right on the map, killing rats that appear predictably from corridors bordering the map. There is not much replay value, and maps are very linear.
- Not nearly as many scenario types (rescue missions, etc.) as XCOM.
- You'll either like the pixelart or dislike it. For me, it's a bit too pixely - I had trouble at times telling certain characters apart.
- Music and sounds are fantastic. Probably the best part of the game for me.
- The game is moderately challenging. It's not 'easy' as some might say, but once you learn the basic mechanics it's not hard to figure out the best placements for characters. 
- Each character has a mostly different role, though some are definitely more useful than others.
- The story is not very good; neither is the theme, at least not for me. It's mostly just there to provide an excuse to do some turn based tactics gameplay.
- The price is exactly where it should be for this game.

I sound negativem, but the game is still quyite fun for what it is. Don't expect the variety or polish of XCOM. Mechanics are shallow, but the gameplay loop of turn based tactics is satisfying enough, and the game is short enough, to make it worth it for the price. Kudos to the publisher for setting the price to what it should be for what you get.

For less than 20$? Absolutely recommend if you enjoy city build or are looking for a quirky and accessible entry in the genre. Even for early access i already feel like I've gotten my money's worth of enjoyment and time. Art is charming, and the world is whimsical. The detail in the houses/decorations make towns feel more real and alive. It's fun to just sit back and watch the world go.

There are some kinks to work out in regards to food supply imo, but nothing game breaking at the moment. It seems as if almost 1/2 of my land is devoted to vegetables, creating a constant need of an army of low level citizens to run them (farms are one of the, if not the, only building limited to low level citizens). But this seems like something that will likely be tweaked, or remedied by higher level food sources/buildings we don't have access to yet. 

I love the little event scenarios you can uncover. I've had a few that give some cosmetic decorations, and one that gave a permanent buff (and was a talking tree. love that). Hoping to see more of the later, so the events can feel more impactful and permanent in the world.

TLDR; It's cute, quirky, and strangely relaxing for a city sim. Huge fan.

It's nice to see and play a relaxing city builder for once. Graphics are cute and fit the storybook/fairy aesthetic well. The devs have been quite transparent in their roadmap and responds to a lot of questions over their discord too. Very excited to see further development into the game!

I went into this game with meh expectations and was shocked at just how great it was. Fairly short game but the jumpscares were mind blowing. It sometimes had an Observer feel, sure it was no where near the Cyberpunk that that game was, but at least I felt it took a little from that. I think maybe the pricetag is scaring off a few from giving it a shot, but after I finished I recommended all my horror friends to give this a look see. There was one jump scare that caused me to knock off everything from my little table, everything flew off the table, my mouse flew and I flew LOL. Also I felt like the game was fairly easy to run, the controls were fairly easy. Puzzles were few and far between, but what was there was easy to solve. Graphics were amazing so no complaints there, it did get a little dark at times, but that can be adjusted somewhat in the menu. Yall give this game a shot you won't be disappointed.

P.S This was my first review so sorry if it wasn't polished enough. I just had to say something about this game.

I think this is mostly good and very impressive for being a solo dev project.
The art style is amazing, and I love the environments for most of the levels, with the city, the dali world, and the 2nd to last level being the highlights and my favorite levels in general. 

Shooting is very basic and turning enemies into gore is always fun, but the gunplay and enemy variety is probably the weakest part of the game, especially since by the halfway point you've seen everything and the game never throws new mechanics at you.

Music is also good. The last thing I'll say is with an aesthetic this great I wish there was a little more going on with narrative, and things that tied the levels and characters together, because it's close to feeling cohesive and interesting but nothing really backs it up. I do like that what little story there is, is told entirely visually.

I think if the dev decides to do another project I'd love to see a slower paced exploration, puzzle or even horror game that really gives you time to milk the art design and environments

Love this game. I plan to do a full video review at some point, but I'll summarize my feelings here for now. 20 dollars and a 3-hour first playthrough well-spent.

There is no real story to this game. By the dev's own admission. I...kinda hate that John Carmack "story in video games is like story in porn" quote, but I do like how little is elaborated on here. It doesn't just leave things open to interpretation, but it also leaves the game unshackled from any kind of "canon" it has to build on. With that said, the little setpieces and environmental storytelling does create this sense of a connected experience I quite enjoy.

Speaking of setpieces and environments, this game oozes style. Every level is distinct in aesthetic, and often uses assets entirely unique form other levels. It's creepy and cartoony and deliciously visceral. I believe it's heavily implied to be a sort of dream that the player is experiencing. To that end, I kind of wish there was more abstract level design. Maybe titles like Anemoiopolis and MyHouse.wad spoiled me too much, but despite the surreal environments, the worlds often feel surprisingly grounded and cohesive. If there were ever any sort of sequel to this title, I hope the dev leans into things like what they did with the mirrors in Mystique House and go all-out with that non-euclidian space warping. I love that stuff any day of the week, and I cannot get enough.

Oh yeah and the OST slaps like a motherfucker. I've been calling it "Burtoncore," since that seems to evoke the sense of what you can expect from it. synthey, playful, but at the same time sinister and foreboding.

The gameplay is pretty simple. You got a jump and a double jump, and a bunch of guns that will feel pretty familiar to your average FPS enjoyer. Notable exceptions to this are the Microwave Gun - a replacement for your standard automatic which has the notable benefit of blowing up enemies if you can train your beam on them long enough. Think the Amid Evil Voltride, but much easier to pull off consistently. Also, the Worm Gun. I love the Worm Gun. One of the most unique and interesting guns in the game - and most fps games. Shoot a leech at your foes, set it and forget it (sorta like a Blood Flare Gun), but once it does its business, the leech becomes saturated with blood - and depending how much it got to feed, you can, uh...eat it. And heal up to 10hp! Try using it on the Pigbots!

Even though most of the other weapons don't do anything terribly unique, they still feel great. You'll pick up an AR later on which is functionally superior to your base Shotgun in every way, but I still used the Shotgun. Because shooting it felt great and so does the flip-cock. I'm a sucker for flips and cock. We've all seen Grenade Launchers, but Illwill's firing speed and arc feels so satisfying. Once you play around with it a bit, it can start feeling almost second-nature to land direct hits with it. It isn't quite Blood TNT levels of intuition, but it's very close.

That said, there is some bloat to the weapon roster. Some redundancy in your guns. Regundancy, if you will. I think the game could remove the Rocket Launcher, Assault Rifle, and Soul Extractor, and not lose much besides additional ammo pools. The Soul Extractor is kind of interesting - killing Painheads with it won't cause them to explode when they die, and as far as I can tell, it prevents the target from shooting at you - but it's really just a high-damage automatic, and its little nuances rarely play a factor in how you use it.

The weapon balance migh have some misses in my option, but the enemy balance is EXCELLENT. Every enemy has a unique role, and the ways they play off of eachother, around the arenas, and against you makes for some great-feeling combat.

One other thing I'd like to mention: I really love the game's secret collectible. By collecting one of the three violins in each level, the player can increase their damage within that level by 10% - up to 30% with all 3. What a cool little reward for exploration! If you got good secret-hunting skills, you're rewarded with shorter kill times on automatics and in some cases, better kill thresholds on your shotguns and explosives! I really like that. :)

Overall, I'd give this game a 4/5. Really good, solid title. I really like a lot of the systems here. But it could stand to be refined a little. If I ever see DLC or a followup to this in the future, I'll be snapping it up in an instant. Until then, I'm gonna 100% the shit outta this game.

[h1][b][1] Intro [/b][/h1]
Is It Wrong to Repay the Debt in a Dungeon? is a card battle RPG game that revolves around a story of a mother and daughter trying to pay off their debt by exploring dungeons, challenging strong enemies, and even using their own bodies.

[h1][b][2] Game Experience[/b][/h1]

One of the main attractions of this game is its card battle system, which is easy to learn but challenging to master. The game features a well-balanced card battle system with over 60 kinds of cards that can be upgraded to fight against various enemies. Players can choose the most appropriate card to defeat enemies in various dungeons and challenges.

The game also features a roguelike RPG game style where players must explore different dungeons and face various enemies. The game's level design is impressive, and each dungeon feels unique and challenging. Players must utilize their cards strategically to progress through the game's levels. Additionally, the game has an in-game achievement system, which encourages players to explore more of the game and collect various items. The game's achievement system adds an extra layer of fun and replayability to the game.

It is worth mentioning that this game contains adult-only events. The voice acting in the game is also noteworthy, providing a rich and engaging experience. The publisher has provided a special H-patch that enables players to access the game's full content, including the adult-only events. It is important to note that this feature is entirely optional and can be turned off in the game's settings.

[h1][b][3] Verdict [/b][/h1]
Overall, Is It Wrong to Repay the Debt in a Dungeon? is an enjoyable and unique card battle RPG game that offers a compelling story, challenging gameplay, and impressive level design. It is well worth checking out, especially for fans of the genre. However, it is important to keep in mind that the game contains adult-only content that can only be accessed through the H-patch provided by the publisher.

If I had to describe [i]Hunt the Night[/i] in it's current state, I would say it feels unfinished, almost like it should have been released in early access for some extra polish.

Don't get me wrong, there's a lot going for the game: the pixel art, the music, the atmosphere, the world-building, the puzzles.

But there's just so many bad and confusing design choices that, despite 100%ing the game, leave me not wanting to recommend it until they work on it a bit more.

The biggest issue I have is with the combat: enemies have busted hitboxes, hit just a little too hard, and the combat is too clunky to allow you to handle encounters effectively. There's no animation-cancelling and no permanent way beyond gear to increase your attack or defense, just your HP, and beyond the max healing charges of 5, lifesteal is your only way of getting health back despite not working on everything. You can also poison enemies, but the proc chance and damage are so low it's almost not worth it.

The encounter design in particular is absolutely awful, with the game often swarming you with dozens of enemies, projectiles, or both that respawn between load screens despite the clunky combat not allowing you to handle multiple things going on at once very well. [spoiler]There's also a few bosses that ask the question of, "what if it was the same encounter but now there's two of them? Or what if they can spawn trash mobs infinitely?"[/spoiler]

There are also quite a few enemies that, while they do telegraph their attacks, have such a short reaction window that you're almost guaranteed to take damage from them unless you pick them off using a ranged attack. [spoiler]The invisible guys in particular are extremely annoying to deal with in packs for this reason[/spoiler].

And considering combat, the most tedious aspect of the game, is also the core focus of the game, I found myself opting to run past all of the enemies after a certain point because it was not worth the time it took to fight them.

There's also a few small things I had issue with, such as:

• The dash allowing you to fall off ledges or into bodies of liquid, only for the game to spawn you across the map or in another room entirely instead of the last surface you were standing on
• Cutscenes replaying after failing to defeat certain bosses, instead of skipping straight to the encounter
• One-way trips not having a confirmation before yeeting you into the abyss, resulting in needless backtracking
• Area transitions that are poorly signposted save for some different lighting on the floor
• No maps, although most areas aren't too difficult to navigate
• Hunts not being marked as complete at the tavern
• No audiovisual feedback when your dark energy is full or cooldown is over
• No bestiary or game stats menu
• Not enough weapon, gear, and enemy variety
• Bizzare and jarring load-stutters when saving or transitioning to a new area

Also, there's a pretty major softlock after completing a puzzle (that resets itself if you get it wrong for some reason) in the final dungeon, [spoiler]Bloodisfell Cathedral,[/spoiler] and some other bugs such as levers getting stuck, players not being able to attack, getting stuck in geometry, and  item pickup notifications not appearing or using the wrong template. [spoiler]The Apothecary keys didn't have notifications and the white snake scale used the default NPC dialogue instead of the item notification[/spoiler].

But with all that being said I definitely think the game is worth keeping an eye on, so give it a few months or wait for a sale if it looks interesting.

Disclaimer: The free key is because I was a Kickstarter backer.

When I came across this game I was very suspicious of yet ANOTHER city builder...I gave it a chance and read into the details:
The Art style is INCREDIBLY cute, and unique. The game is brightly colored, many flowers and the water is fun. You can also click around the map and it reacts to your click (I loved this a little too much...) 
The animals are SO cute and I am looking forward to seeing more added in eventually...(Horses are my favorite winkwink Grenaa Games)

The Narrator is SO funny and very cute with the little comments he makes here and there, but by NO means is he overbearing or annoying like some games have. 
The tutorials give you rewards instead of just being blunt and annoying, and the jobs they give are very calming and peaceful. 

As someone that suffers immensely with mental illnesses, PTSD, Depression, Anxiety and more...This game is a god sent. I cannot wait to see where this game goes, if you're looking for a great one to relax to this is it, consider supporting it's growth!

What is there is enjoyable and hints at what is to come with more development time. The art style is charming. The UI is clean and easy to navigate. The game does a good job of introducing the new mechanics in bite size, easy to understand portions. The framework is there for a great game. There are some interesting elements that i havent seen in this genre before such as a player controlled hero which has equipable items. It also seems as though they will be adding armies later. There is political relations with neighbors with which you build either positive or negative relationships with. I hope that multiplayer is added at some point. It seems doable at some point and would be interesting to see in this genre.

You can Pet the dog Cat and their owners, Ok , maybe not the last one

Product received for free as a content creator.

Pros: 
- Cute dog/cat animations when playing with toys
- Diversity in pets with inclusion of fish, rabbits, turtles
- Pet 'perks' (should be called traits..) add good diversity to gameplay
- It's frantic enough to keep you busy, making sinking time into it easy.

Cons:
- The mini-games for playing with pets are a bit boring, and often feel unnecessary or slow. If they were more entertaining and fast paced, the experience would be better
- Dogs/Cats can clip through walls, fences, gates, doors etc. I released my dogs into my yard and had to chase them all across the world to get them back. And I had a cat who just couldn't be contained.
- Having to manually input booking info isn't a good gameplay choice as it adds nothing but a bit of annoyance. I'd remove it, and have booking info input automatically after you accept the pet through a phone call.
- There should be an option to adopt your own pet that can free-roam the hotel whilst you're there, it'd be fun to name one and look after it yourself.
- The tutorials are too long and should be integrated as tooltips into the actual gameplay, not as separate missions.

I've been looking forward to the debut game of my good friend Mr. ErkBerg. And here it finally is: Recollection is a relaxing exploration game. No stress, just exploring, finding interesting things in the environment and enjoying the beautiful graphics in the purple night sky... oh and passing some mini games. Some of them might be difficult to grasp at first. No in-game tutorial tells you how to pass them, you have the freedom to find it out by yourself, I like that aspect!

The art style might remind you of Limbo at the first sight, but in a much gentler mood.
To be honest: I had to turn the music volume a great bit down to listen more from the sound effects. Maybe a quieter default for the music could be good.

If you like games like Proteus then Recollection with its rich explorable environment aspect might be interesting to you.

All in all a pretty solid first game as a young solo indie game dev. I'm astonished how beautiful it went out!

Congratulations, Dear ErkBerg!

First I'd like to reiterate, I adored the prologue, I've played too many hours of it, so it's with a heavy heart that I can't currently recommend this game.

I will say, the decorating tool is one of the best I've seen in any game, at all, it's outstanding that we have triple A titles that cost hundreds to be complete, yet this comes along and blows it out of the water from graphics to accessibility/creating. 

However, I feel like the 2 modes we get on starting up the game, leave something to be desired for. Challenge mode, which is the only "career" mode feels like it throws you in the deep end, I restarted 4 times alone because the amount of animals to handle from day one was overwhelming to say the least. Every room was full, most animals had low needs from the get go, even after cleaning, clipping, washing, feeding, double checking feeding, then play, play play, and boom I hadn't enough time before an animal had serious mood decay. 

Then sandbox mode goes the extreme in the other way, nothing feels like it matters, the challenge is gone which was a main draw for me to enjoy this game, I'd like the game a lot more with a balanced experience, I feel like there isn't much in between the animals moods all decaying, which feels totally random aswell. I remember having to feed a single fish 3 times in a single day and by the time I had done this single thing, 5 animals all needed to be played with in separate, slow interactions.

Unfortunately I don't wanna beat a dead horse, I hope in future updates the balancing is expanded more as this game has some of the most perfect ingredients I've come across in a simulation/Strategy game, it gives me old Nintendogs and relaxing time wasters, it's just the strategy needs some polishing for me to feel I can enjoy it yet :)

I was curious if I would enjoy this game, so I just tried it after a very stressful day of work. While playing I kept thinking about game development and other creative passions and the struggles they come with. Forgetting why you love what you do, or that you loved it once, because others are throwing stones at you when you try following your passion.

This game is about nature, but for me it felt so much like it wasn't "only" about the nature outside, but although the nature of creativity/ideas inside of us (our mind, heart or soul or whatever you want to call it) which are being destroyed or forgotten over the time of our life.

The mini games were nice, diverse and satisfying to play and watch. I liked how the character watched the grass growing. And collecting the birds and clouds, or drawing the star constellations without knowing what the final shape would be.

When I started the fragile mode, I wasn't sure if there was a point in trying to "clean" the moon, or if I was meant to fail. But in the end I made it. The fragile mode was definitely a challenge compared to the first story mode, but it was a fair one. 

What I really liked about this small game as well was how intuitive it was. I didn't need any explanations or tutorial to understand what i'm supposed to do. And those simple animations and nudging highlights that showed up when I waited a bit did help, they didn't feel annoying at all.

Cute game, worth giving a try at the current price point.
Would definitely recommend leveraging the highlight enemies option the dev made me aware of in his response, made a huge difference for visual clarity.

Small People Defense is a charming tower defense title. The price point is staggeringly low and for the amount of content you get, it's an absolute steal. It's only in early access but the game already feels so fluid and fun!

I am a huge fan of tower defense and generally try to play as many of them as I can and this is one of the better titles I've seen recently. The unique interactions between towers are challenging to use and the added strategic depth is a welcome addition.

The first few levels I played had me restricted to only 2 towers but I still had difficulties completing them with 3 stars (you get ranked out of 3). However, this didn't seem to affect the amount of points I had to spend in the out-of-game upgrade screen to too much of a significant degree which I felt was fair and nicely done.

You quickly gain access to more towers, more levels and upgrades. The strategies and enemy variety are great and I cannot wait to play more. I especially like how each tower has an individual targeting behavior instead of merely targeting the closest target. For example, the fire tower targets only enemies that are not yet "on fire" and as such spreads the debuff evenly between them, which is a fantastic mechanic in my opinion.

The points you gain from completing levels can be spent on upgrades that provide more starting money, more HP for your base, higher DPS for whichever tower you choose and so on. They are also spent on unlocking new levels. The points required for new level unlocks are again fair and not at all costing the world which means the developer respects your time and doesn't force you to grind constantly to unlock things.

The way towers work in the game was a refreshing change as well, they use a projectile based system where placement of towers actually has a profound effect on how efficient each tower is. For example, place a tower perpendicular and far away from the enemy path? You're going to have problems killing much at all! But place it in line or along the angle of the path? Now you'll be cooking with gas! This is just one of many things I noticed in the game that I really appreciated.

The only thing I would like to see implemented is a way to toggle/an option in the game menu to see an overlay of what upgrade level each tower has without you having to run to it with your character and checking, so seeing it at a glance would be beneficial. Especially in larger levels where you may not be able to manage many towers too easily. The upgrades are represented already as each tower grows larger in size but this is sometimes a little obtuse as you may not easily notice the difference between level 5 or level 6. A minor thing to be sure but it would definitely be a welcome improvement.

Overall, I have a lot of fun with the game and I hope to be able to find some time to play more soon!

A good introduction to the mechanics and the world, but it can't stand on its own because of the excessive fourth-wall breaking and unplayable combat on the hardest setting.

The vibrant graphics are the first thing you notice. Although the art style has been seen before and it’s not particularly original, it somehow makes the game stand out. The game has a third-person view with a rotatable camera when you're outside, but as soon as you enter a house or other enclosed area, the camera switches to a static top-down view.

The story is filled with comedy and moments where characters break the fourth wall. In my opinion, they go too far with these. Everything has to be a joke, a reference to something modern, the awareness of being in a videogame, etc. 

The characters mainly smile and move around in smooth animations with a few different facial expressions to convey mood. Talking to people is done very well. To ensure that you don't miss anything, whenever they speak, a speech bubble appears over their head. While the majority of them may be easily ignored if you don't want to hear their mundane words, you must pay attention to the blue speech bubbles that advance the plot.

However, interaction with the world adopts a traditional style that makes things easy to overlook. What I mean by this is that hotspots aren’t marked. Some things like chests are obvious, but some are very random. You might try interacting with several cupboards and get no feedback, but then you interact with another that looks exactly the same and find something new. Even though these are optional and solely contribute to the world-building, it’s still a shame to hide them like this.

The world has a distinctive appearance since it is formed of blocks. With the exception of high places, the exploring is mostly pleasant. It's odd that your heroine has to face challenges every time she tries to reach higher spots. Imagine a set of stairs; if you take each step in order, you can climb a hill; if you try to skip a step, you'll run into a wall. This is the simplest approach to illustrate the issue.  

Everything conforms to the traditional JRPG structure. This entails fighting in random and turn-based battles, purchasing and equipping new gear, using items, etc. The use of skills is the slightly different mechanic. These operate on points that carry over to subsequent battles and gradually recharge after each turn. 

Even though you control only three fighters at a time, your party can have up to six characters who can step in to take the place of the active fighter when their turn comes. Although it may seem like you'll have an easier time, a character's death throws everything out of the window. Because a healthy character won't automatically take its position after being knocked down and because you can't switch it until you bring it back from the dead, the problem is that a downed character is practically a dead weight. An extremely odd and senseless design decision. 

Another weird decision is the inclusion of difficulty settings. This should be removed. While playing on easy level makes sense if you want to focus on the story, playing on hard makes the game absolutely unplayable because of unbalanced encounters. You’re constantly walking back to your bed to heal after every battle or wasting revive items on companions who are killed in one hit.

But what I really found interesting is the mechanic where you fill out information about enemies. Each enemy begins with a card that is entirely blank and has only question marks. From health and experience points to status effects and drops, this card has it all.

Information can be obtained in a variety of ways. You have three options: utilize a scan magic, defeat the enemy, or hit it with various weapons, which is the least useful approach because you don't always have everything in your arsenal. If you keep fighting, you will eventually obtain all of the data since at least one piece of information will be filled out each time you scan or eliminate an enemy. The perk of collecting info is that you can skip a fight.

Pets Hotel is a simulation game in which you run an animal hotel. Feed, care for and entertain your guests to make a profit. Improve the hotel and attract new customers. The game has nice graphics and funny characters.

I do recommend the game if you like animal and simulator this one is for you

-I love the fact that you can create your own hotel from scratch gives some creativity to your game content 
-the graphics are fine to me and and I usually am picky so they’re fine 
-the gameplay is the same as any simulator. It gets repetitive but wich game isn’t when you think about it not a problem for me
-I love the customization of items
-the animals are cute you can pet them play with them and take care of them
-I like the small game that comes with nails clipping and playing with animals 
-I like adding the names and information at the beginning in the computer makes it lot more realistic 
I think so far my only negative point is
- I would like to have a calendar and you can deal with your in and out animal, further than for the next day like getting a call from a guest that want a spot for his dog in a week instead but that is minor would just add to realist and planing that’s it. 

Overall I do recommend I love the game and the dev did a good job bringing this to us 🥰

Finished it completely and got the bad ending unfortunately (missed 2 cards) but other than that it was a great experience. Combat felt a little repetitive after awhile but the new enemy types made it refreshing enough to finish. I would recommend this game tbh. The first 15 minutes are actually terrifying but the rest of the time its just puzzles. If you're looking for a consistent horror experience i recommend outlast. I had a lot of fun playing this. It;s a very good adventure horror. I thought the mini bosses were really interesting too. My full playthrough of this game :)

Such a Great Game! Amazing Concept and Perfect Delivery!

I enjoyed what I played, however if I could give a thumbs sideways I might have depending on how the game plays later on.
My main issue is that the upgrades feel extrememly meh so far, and are spread very thin early on which makes dying feel really bad. If drop rates in chests or random item spawns in rooms was increased just a little bit to make it feel like restarting a new run felt good that would be excellent, but as for now the first 15 minutes of the game are extremely boring and have possibly turned me off from touching this game again.

I do recommend it for it's overall feel, themes and polish, the gameplay loop however is one of the biggest misses in the genre.

Doomed Lands is a top-down pixel art survival game where the player is transported to a post-apocalyptic environment where the world is dominated by horrible and mutant creatures. The goal of the game is to survive as long as possible while facing these threats, collecting resources, and fighting for your life.

One of the highlights of Doomed Lands is its atmosphere. The pixel art graphics, with a dark and somber color scheme, add a sense of despair and constant danger. The soundtrack also contributes to this atmosphere, with ambient sounds that bring the game world to life and add tension to the most dangerous moments.

The gameplay of Doomed Lands is challenging, with limited resources and threats around every corner. The player needs to manage their hunger, thirst, and energy, as well as dealing with hostile monsters and other dangers that arise as they progress through the game world. There is also the possibility of encountering other survivors who may help or hinder the player, adding an extra layer of complexity and unpredictability to the game.

A negative point of Doomed Lands is the lack of variety in terms of enemies and resources. Although there are some different types of monsters and resources, overall, the game can become repetitive after a few hours of gameplay.

However, overall, Doomed Lands is a solid and well-executed top-down pixel art survival game. With its dark atmosphere and challenging gameplay, it offers an immersive and engaging gaming experience for players seeking an intense challenge.

A great little indie arcade gem for a really low price. 

Though the developer has released titles on other platforms in the past, Soulvester VS Lil' Beezey is the first Steam release from developer Chaz Carter and it's a fantastic debut. The game has the same chaotic fun energy of classic Newgrounds hits, with the polish and quality of a modern release. The voice acting by Dicky Carter is perfect and gives me the same fun vibe as titles like BattleBlock Theater. The gameplay is fast and responsive, the sound effects are satisfying and everything about it oozes charm - it had me grinning from ear to ear as I finished my first run. 

There's still room for improvement: the game is extremely short and replay value is limited (outside of posting high scores), but it's still a bargain at the current price and this could easily be fixed in a future update by adding some form of meta progression, like adding more upgrades to the pool as you unlock achievements. 

Overall, it's a brilliant way to spend an hour and I'd fully recommend showing the developer some support.
its fine

Game is very over the top and I love it for that. 

Its "hard" at first definitely designed around meta progression making it easier to win.

Controller menu navigation is weird at times(mostly in the main and meta level up) but no issues with moving around and leveling up.
Had a good time. Will come back....
Sensational, with super well-made gameplay and an intelligent progression system, so it's guaranteed fun. And that's because it's still in EA.

The game is a new aproach in roguelikes survivors. It's beautiful and well balanced! Lots of fun! Recommended!

As an avid gamer, I recently had the opportunity to play Energy Survivors on Steam, and I must say, I was thoroughly impressed! One of the standout aspects of this game for me was the music and overall game feel, which truly enhanced my gaming experience.

The music in Energy Survivors is absolutely captivating. The soundtrack features a perfect blend of futuristic electronic beats, intense battle themes, and haunting melodies that perfectly complement the game's sci-fi setting. The music dynamically shifts based on the in-game situations, creating a seamless and immersive experience. I found myself getting lost in the game's world, thanks in part to the engaging and atmospheric soundtrack that kept me hooked from start to finish.

In addition to the outstanding music, the overall game feel in Energy Survivors is exceptional. The controls are smooth and responsive, allowing for precise aiming and movement, which is crucial in a third-person shooter game. The animations are fluid, and the graphics are visually stunning, creating a visually appealing and immersive world to explore. The roguelite mechanics add an element of replayability, as each run presents new challenges and opportunities for experimentation with different upgrades.

I also appreciated the variety of upgrades available in the game, which allowed me to create unique and powerful builds to suit my playstyle. Experimenting with different combinations of upgrades was not only fun but also strategic, as I had to carefully choose my upgrades to adapt to the challenges of the hostile planet I was exploring.

Overall, Energy Survivors left a lasting impression on me with its incredible music and game feel. The captivating soundtrack and immersive gameplay made for an unforgettable gaming experience. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys third-person shooters with roguelite elements, as Energy Survivors delivers an outstanding gameplay experience that will keep you coming back for more.

So far this game has an awesome base for an incredible game! As a guitarist I really enjoyed the tutorial building a guitar and the gameplay felt a lot like PC Building Simulator and Car Mechanic Simulator. I would totally recommend downloading this and giving it a shot. The UI could use some work, it's kinda confusing progressing to the next step once you're done and seeing what is actually required for the build. Also maybe seeing where stuff is missing while painting would be nice. Besides that and the fact that the demo is time locked I really enjoyed the experience.
LOVED ALL OF IT! Those piggies are hard to find

I thought the game was just okay, not much content though, it only has 4 stages and +2 bonus levels, so about 60 minutes on normal difficulty. Also, I had a few small problems with the clipping on the hitbox, for example whenever you have to dash between any spikes, sometimes it's a bit tricky to avoid the walls. I think one area took me about 10 tries, and in general, I feel like the dev went a little crazy on the enemy spam. That said, you can lower the difficulty which will negate the HP problems, but the game is still has a few weird platforming sections.

One thing I would recommend is to have at least 2 areas per biome, most devs would stretch the themes for a couple of stages, but you only had 1 or 2 areas for the same visuals; If you already created enough assets to make the level look unique, you might as well make it last for more than 10 minutes. A few other small nitpicks I have, some of the thorns had a very similar color to the ground, might want to make it a bit darker, and I was a bit confused by the damage, some enemies seem to do 1 damage, and others are doing 2 or 3?

Other than that, I thought the levels and the cutscenes looked decent, with a few cute moments in the narrative. 

[h1] Pros: [/h1]

(+) Well, the game is mostly average in every aspect, aside from a few polish issues, it plays decently, it looks okay, music is nice (not sure if made for the game), and it has a few funny scenes.

[h1] Feedback: [/h1]

[u] Content [/u] - you have enough variety between the stages, but I felt like you didn't make enough actual platforming between the zones, like you have stages that look nice, but only 1 area per theme. Usually, devs will make 3 or 4 areas per zone, so you could use what you already have and just make more platforming content. Even one of the bonus stages looks like a dungeon, but you didn't really use those tiles much. 

[u] Gameplay [/u] - the thorns need a bit of color coding. I had some issues with the tight spots between the spikes, easy to clip the hitbox, maybe make those areas a bit wider so you not hitting the ceiling all the time. The platforming momentum felt just slightly off to me, I think he falls down just slightly too fast, and the base walking speed without running probably should be a bit higher. 

[b] Overall Thoughts: 6/10 [/b]

The biggest thing for me, like I said, you have different themes, but only 1 area per location for the most part, usually it's 3 or 4 right, you don't even need to make more assets, just use those that you already have to make more content.I felt like the level design was a bit crowded in terms of hazards, even though the game plays decently it's very easy to feel like something is unfair. The game is technically not bad, it just feels like you didn't fully optimize the stages so there are some small moments that can be frustrating. I think you need to make the movement a bit more gradual in the mid-air.
