O jogo "Zumbi Blocks 2 Open Alpha" é um exemplo impressionante de como um desenvolvedor talentoso pode criar uma obra-prima. Desde o seu lançamento, o jogo tem atraído uma grande quantidade de jogadores entusiastas de jogos de tiro em primeira pessoa, e por um bom motivo. O jogo é divertido, emocionante e desafiador, oferecendo aos jogadores uma experiência de jogo imersiva e viciante.

O desenvolvedor por trás do jogo, demonstrou habilidades notáveis na criação do jogo. Desde a jogabilidade até os gráficos, tudo no jogo é feito com maestria e atenção aos detalhes. Os controles são intuitivos e fáceis de usar, permitindo que os jogadores se concentrem na ação e na aventura. A variedade de armas e equipamentos disponíveis no jogo é impressionante e oferece aos jogadores uma ampla gama de opções para enfrentar os zumbis.

O desenvolvedor do "Zumbi Blocks 2 Open Alpha" provou que é possível criar jogos excelentes sem precisar de grandes recursos ou de uma grande empresa por trás. Eles demonstraram que com talento e dedicação, é possível criar jogos até melhores que os de grandes desenvolvedoras como a "Ubisoft". O jogo é uma verdadeira obra-prima e um exemplo de excelência na indústria de jogos.
Obrigado por trazer essa pérola de volta a vida, que nostalgia!

This is a very early build for a project that I am very interested in seeing progressed further. Yes there is not much to do, the developer took a little project and let us have a look at it and get feedback. I love the boss fight concept, cant wait to see more and to mix with difficulty increasing over time actually works pretty well. Permadeath would make this early alpha have more replayability but for testing purposes I understand why it doesn't. Keep up the good work man.+

[h1]Experienced on the Meta Quest 2[/h1]

You can view my initial impressions review & gameplay here: https://youtu.be/9S853VgxaAY

One of the best, if not the best, free to play VR music rhythm games on Steam. It's really just a notch or two below Audio Trip or Synth Riders. It's got a pretty good soundtrack from Yandex Music that I was actually digging.

It looks nice. The gameplay is solid (just not as good as Synth Riders or Audio Trip). The visuals look really good for a free to play title. The music is pretty good. You get a very good workout as well. 

Game is running on the Unity Engine. On my RTX 3080, I was getting mostly 90 fps, with just some drops here and there that did not effect gameplay. You can play seated or standing (game is much easier playing seated). Beware though: even on easy, this is quite the workout. You'll have to do some squats to reach the orbs when they are placed low. That's the main reason why I had to tap out after 30 minutes (I'm out of shape though).

[b]Rate 8/10. Not sure why it's free, but I'll take it.[/b]

I had written off the rogue-lite 'Survivors' style genre, but this game does a great job of taking things in its own direction and running with the mech theme. It's good fun and does a lot of little things that keep it feeling polished. I wouldn't think it's an early access release if I didn't see the banner.

Having to navigate and consider your facing orientation helps give this a more challenging edge than it's peers in terms of action, and it's fun just running around bashing some of the little enemy units. Still feels like I'm early into it, but I'm hoping to see some more weaponry and tactics that use the strafe vs random targeting since that's a key feature that makes it feel unique.

The format gives you more tangible goals too (reach wave 15) vs. open ended survive as long as possible which I appreciate. Animations are solid, you can tell a lot of work was done to not only get a lot of enemies on screen but also give you plenty of nice destruction effects going on.

Controller support at launch is a plus and the price point is plenty fair.

First impressions, pretty good. Straightforward progression that doesn't feel like a grind, surviving the onslaught can be addicting, and overall feeling of the game feels very rewarding. A definite recommend from me.

Some criticisms I would give to the game:
-The music is fine but the sound effects are a bit too "sharp" and it kinda hurts the ears after a while.
-There was no way to refer to the controls after the initial level. It would be nice to have a controls list in the pause menu.
-Trying to line up the mech using the Spacebar was also a bit frustrating as you're weaving around enemies and running straight eventually leads to running into a big crowd.
-The lack of control over the mech itself. I feel like this game is designed more for mobile in mind, so maybe that's the point, but I was really hoping to pilot the mech and have some control over the actions I performed other than WASD. Maybe have an option to automate/manually control certain actions, as well as be able to make the mech spin using the mouse (or using the arrow keys?) independently from movement. This also made it particularly frustrating when trying to fight the bosses, as I couldn't put my focus on any specific type of enemy.

So far, everything else is good and looking forward to playing more. Hope the best for future updates!

Okay so first off I'll lead this review by saying that it is a good game, the charting is excellent and it's insanely fun to play for what it is. However there are two glaring issues, one has a work around, one doesn't. The horizontal note lane is fucking atrocious for reading notes, especially if you come from any other rhythm game ever made. There's a reason with Taiko no Tatsujin and Muse Dash limit the game to just two note types, because horizontally the notes become overwhelming to read. This can be fixed by flipping your monitor into portrait mode through Windows however, though you're stuck with mirrored notes if you need downscroll. The second issue is that the health bar is just too far away from the rest of the information, this is a rhythm game so your eyes are glued to a certain part of the screen at all times, and they designed the ultra and EX meters well enough with this in mind, however, the health is on the complete opposite end of the screen making it pretty much a no go to look at unless you're on a simple part of the song and your opponent isn't completely ruining you with garbage. It's a fun game but it needs some sort of UI customization, which is something that many people were asking for in the discussions and it seemed like the creators of this game refused to listen to them. As is I can't fully recommend this game since you have to physically flip your screen or with a setting to be able to play it well.

Brief comment of producer Yang Zhongping

As a gamer playing this game since 2022, I feel like it’s necessary to introduce our dear official to fellow gamers.

1, producer Yang the fatty has worked in several companies, like ByteDance and Xindong. Eventually he joined Mihoyo’s dev team and scammed more than 100 million RMB (about 15million USD) with only 20 men and within 2 years. These money are all for his own purpose, like larger apartments and cars in Shanghai. Although his project in Mihoyo was eventually killed, Liu Wei, the CEO of Mihoyo still allowed him to take all project-related resource for his own game. When the beta test of this game started, all Mr. Yang did is to reap gamers’ wallets. A typical banner is 10 rolls with 200 RMB, and only get a guarantee after 150 rolls. 

2, Yang takes a rough attitude towards players’ reporting, he would ban accounts which are innocent, simply because they were reported by their opponents. Whenever you feel like your opponent in this match is using game mechanics as an advantage or simply unhappy today, then report your opponent and you will never see him again. Yang also forces gamers to follow his rule and never listen to suggestions, even if himself doesn’t understand how his game works. Last but not least, Yang would release update patch during the critical moment of a match (a typical match usually lasts 2-3 days) and the server maintenance would last hours, resulting in players losing advantage.

3, as a producer of the game, Yang hacks every time he fight against real players. As an ordinary gamer, I’m lucky enough to meet this occasion once and witnessed him hacking during a live stream. When we are about to complain about this, Yang emphasized that he created the game and no one shall oppose him. He doesn’t care about players’ account and threatened to sell them. We have never received any apologies for this.

4, Yang has been avaricious, he only cares about money but not gamers. Adding in-game purchase in RTS??? I’m sure EN players would meet “unlimited corner turret” and more unreasonable things in the future. He also added in-game ADs as a bonus, which is simply because his Taobao account was reported and he needs another way to reap gamers. Now he has a EN server, and in-game purchase would be activated again to take money from your wallets, legally. 

5, recently the price for a vehicle banner has raised from 10 rolls a guarantee to 40 rolls a guarantee, forcing gamers to pay much more money to obtain full game experience. Unlike other gacha games, players who refuse to pay abundant money in this game have very little game experience.

6, Yang was also found in Wechat selling players’ accounts which have been permanently banned by him. As stated before, Yang takes an arbitrary attitude in banning accounts, and these accounts which have abundant resources along with full arsenal are sold at a much lower price. In summary, players are viewed as four-leg livestock, awaiting to be reaped randomly.

From close test to beta test, this game has already witnessed a great loss of population in merely several months. Strongly suggest whoever still playing this game not to pay, and if possible, not to play. There are better games in Steam, and there’s no need to stick to this piece of shit. Just let Yang the fatty being the dictator, since there are only two guys left in his dev and he personal attacked his own customer service. The game is failing, and no need to go down with this sinking ship.

Another iteration of Zen Pinball.  Here's my first impression of this version:

1. Ball physics is better on Willams tables, but not necessarily on Zen tables
2. Graphics are a little better, and still very smooth (even of laptop)
3. Sound are a little bit clearer on Willams tables
4. Menu is way better than Pinball FX 3, can get to a table much faster
5. The new tables are nice

Here's what I don't like:

1. 50% discount on table already owned in Pinball FX 3... I can understand that they have to rework some of these tables, but having to buy everything again!!!.  Discount could have higher (like at 75% - 90% discount).  I only bought a few tables I already owned.
2. Still missing some old tables (I would really like to see the "Street Fighter" table and "Ms Splosion Man" table that was made years ago)
3. New ball physics on old zen table takes time to get used to (especially if switching between FX and FX 3)
4. Some server connexion problems

In short, I like it, but I will probably only buy the new tables.  The one I already have, I will play on FX3 (or FX 2)

I have a lot more hours on the epic release of this, but expect my playtime to sky rocket in the next year. 

[u]I understand the controversy behind this release.[/u]

Business model aside, this [i]is[/i] the better way to play. The tables feel much better. As much as I loved FX3, the physics were all over the place and some tables felt very slow and floaty. Others felt like you were playing with a marble rather than a heavy steel pinball. This release addresses all of these issues and makes each tables physics feel unified. Obviously there are some tables that feel faster in pace, but it feels that way now because of the table design rather than the wacky physics. Some tables have become easier, some have become much harder because of this change. And I like this! 

If you can deal with the fact that you'll have to rebuy any tables you previously owned on FX3 (albeit at a discounted price now!) and that some of the new releases come with a premium price tag, you're in for a real treat. Personally, I play a stupid amount of pinball, so the thought of spending £7-£10 on a single table seems like a deal to me. I'd be spending well over £10-£30 playing real physical tables, so to buy and keep some of my favourite real tables for under a tenner is great. I understand that to some this is unacceptable, [i]but this it MILES[/i] better than that god awful ticketing system we had on the epic store.
The tables look great, and play great.

I have had Tray Racers on my wishlist ever since I saw it announced at a gaming showcase a while back. I am glad to get my hands on the release product already, and I have to say I have been enjoying it. Tray Racers is one of the more unique racing games I have played in years and I would easily recommend it to any fan of racing games, or unique indie games. 

 The game is still pretty rough around the edges in some small ways, latency, bugs with menus and a few small kinks that can be worked out, but overall I think this game is a unique and worthwhile experience that would be fun with friends. I hope to see more content in the future.

A cute lil' dungeoning adventure.
A warrior sets out to defeat the evil wizard Sorkin, but ultimately fails...however, thru Sorkin's own necromancy, the hero now has a second chance to fulfill his mission!

You move and attack by clicking, and have a skill bar with a couple of potions, and a stun attack. 

The artstyle is very nice, the environments are spoopy, and the evil skeletons are quite cuddly.

The game plays well, and my only real gripe is you can sometimes get stuck for a moment on corners, and fallen enemies.

I won in a little under 30min. It's simple and cute, and I had a nice time! 
If Part 2 gets made, I'll definitely play it.

Boundary is the most unique shooter to come out in the last 5 years and it breaks my heart that it will soon be another sign that people only want standardized shooters the crosshair travels mainly across the x-axis. I have never seen a shooter with such deliberate mechanics that emphasize gunplay. It takes advantage of the space theme to innovate and improve on the COD formula. Unlike COD, camping is not strong because the game always warns you of enemy presence. Furthermore, tagging enemies temporarily mark them on your minimap, allowing you to ensure your kill. Grenade spam is not encouraged because of the delayed weapon switch and slow rate of usage, ensuring that such utility is used deliberately instead of liberally for lucky kills. These features also serve to prevent complete curb stomping in lobbies by few players because it forces them to temporarily retreat before reengaging. Combined with the ability to turn any "low ground" to "high ground", the game provides the player all the tools necessary to engage the enemy on their terms, only being limited by the player's creativity. I firmly believe that the reviews that criticize this game for it's "lack of replayability" or the "lack of progression" are largely unfound. The player movement allows you to manipulate the map, breaking conventional ideas of positioning and engagement. Every match can be a new way to explore the same map as opposed to a static environment. The game also simplifies unlocking attachments and cosmetics to getting kills with a character with a gun. No need to get 50 kills mounted to a wall or getting 5 kills with a character. Playing the game to unlock all items in the game is a weird feature to criticize especially for a price less than $30 USD.  The failure of this game to survive makes it very clear to people only want the same big esport tactical shooters or battle royales with long battle passes again and again.

The two complaints I do have do not take away from the overall experience but things I hope are ironed out by the time early access ends. The first feature needed is the ability to customize the HUD or make the HUD like other fps. Having the radar not on the top left and the weapons on the right is jarring to see. The second complaint is for the inclusion of louder music. I could play my own music in the background but it would be nice to have atmospheric jazz or classical music picked by the devs playing.

The complaints about servers and frame drops have been addressed by a patch that came out on 4/16, so give the game a shot and provide feedback to help the devs shape this game into something that stays around!

The zero-g combat is very fun, & the weapons & attachments are all earned through gameplay, which is a huge plus. However, there is an incredible amount of sniper spam-- I've played six or seven matches, and in all of them, most of my team & the enemy team were the marksman character. Additionally, there are spawn issues-- in team deathmatch, the game can & will spawn you right next to enemies, who can then kill you before you even move. In other modes, like invasion, the spawns are set, so the best tactic for the defenders is to just spawn camp. 

Also, who thought that putting NA & Asia in the same servers was a good idea? The ping is horrendous. 

For now, I won't recommend this game. But if it gets better I'll change my recommendation.

So, as with most F2P games there is a big element of P2W/P2P. Many a time I have tried so hard to go down the Non-pay route (Sure it takes a lot of time to progress) to see if it can be done and with some games this can be achieved, Eternium being one of them as an example, but this game makes it near on impossible with what can be viewed as hours and hours of grinding just to complete one part of a task (if trying the non-paying style of play). And with the addition of an energy system that depending on what you do determines how quickly it drains. Completing tasks become very laborious, very quickly.

This is a game that is designed to be played by somebody on their phone whilst on a break from work or waiting for a bus. Log on complete one task, log off. It is not designed to be continuously played on PC.

So, I looked up the devs for this game and although it is their first game that they have made and released (from what I could see anyway) what they have created had the potential to be very good but I feel the way they have executed it, is a slight 'dropped the ball' moment, especially with the energy system which is generally viewed in a heavily negative light.

So in conclusion I don't recommend this game for PC but phone, yes.

Hunt the night kinda plays like a spiced up "Link to the past". The combat and exploration are good, story is interesting and the pixel art is lovely.

I wasn't happy with the game at first but it grew on me.
Bloodborne aesthetic with Hyper Light Drifter's style of combat. 
Good art and music. Some interesting puzzles and I think the combat is actually pretty good. Lots of people whining about the combat but it really does boil down to "Git Gud" as annoying as that sounds. The hardest room encounters and bosses only took me a handful of tries at most. 

The game is only about 10 hours long but has some extra content to unlock if you're a real masochist.

My most frustrating gripe is a lack of a map. The game has the Soulsborne approach to progression and exploration where you only get a general hint about where to go but then you're on your own. This would be fine but the game doesn't have enough visual cues in some dungeons to direct you toward the goal and you can totally miss that one door you need to walk through if you just didn't happen to scroll the screen far enough in the right direction. 

There's a couple minor bugs like being able to dash out of bounds occasionally and sometimes the menu stops working. These were few and far between for me.

All in all, totally decent game at the correct price point.

First I wanted to mention that I did experience the line of sight beam disappearing while using a controller. If I’m perfectly honest this didn’t bother me much. And it did not prevent me from completing the game. Aside from that I didn’t experience any other bugs.

The story of Hunt the Night is fairly light, limited to a handful of conversations. However the true depth is in the environmental storytelling present in notes and destruction throughout the world. In addition, the backstory is set up through a world concept of infusing feathers with memories. These provide a lot of detail. And there are about 30 of them in all.

The sound in the game is excellent. The combat sound effects feel appropriate and provide lots of feedback. And the soundtrack is very fitting for the atmosphere of the different biomes present in the game.

The gameplay loop of Hunt the Night is quite fun. You generally solve a few puzzles on the way to the boss room in the five dungeons. The puzzles break up the combat nicely and they are not too difficult. You’ll end up facing 10 main quest bosses and optionally 10 hunt mini bosses, which are supped up versions of normal enemies. As for the enemies themselves there are 17 types that I could count. Every boss encounter was a challenge except for 2 of them. And even the hunt mini bosses were a challenge at times due to the mobs that would also get thrown at you. The 5 dungeons are connected by the overworld which contains a few side quests, lots of hidden items to collect, and some of the mini bosses.

Overall I really enjoyed this game and felt that it was worth every penny! If you enjoyed games like Morbid: The Seven Acolytes, Unsighted, CrossCode, or Tunic, then I think you would like Hunt the Night as well :)

I went into this game a bit blind. I have played Souls games, Bloodborne and Nioh so I have an idea of game difficulty. The game is excellent. The difficulty is up there along with being a bit infuriating and annoying (the whole point of playing these games). Unlike the aforementioned games where if you are killed in game and lose your (souls etc. whatever currency) HTN does not do that. You keep what you kill. Another big plus is save points are right where you need them just before a boss. The music is good, the art is SUPERB. The combat is quick paced. The story is so-so. The lore is excellent. Creepiness and jump factor is definitely in high in there. 

The few janky or bad things about the game are quite minor. From using healing items and spell use if you get hit you can get cancelled (normal in many other games). HTN can use more spells and weapons. I found the layout of your home base of Ravenford  a bit strange with the merchant a bit out of the way.

Overall I really enjoyed this game (as of writing this I'm about 3/4s of the way through the game). I recommend this to all those who are very casual and determined.

The first thing I liked about this game (aside from what I consider a clever name) is the art style.  This rich and beautiful art style that carries through all annual seasons and the detailed animations of working, building, waiting...its fun to just watch what you've built run for awhile every so often.

But what about getting started?  So for a game created by just two guys, I'm STUNNED at how well done it is and this is brought across early when, aside from adopting standard controls, getting them communicated is so well done.  

So let's talk about gameplay.  Like many city builders, you know you're going to need resources, housing, farming, etc...and this is all present in Fabledom, but you also must maintain relationships with other kingdoms.  I have found there might be a balance or AI issue in that I am not getting enough focus on the most critical needs (wood, stone, building), and to that end it would be nice to see a few QOL changes like letting us know how each day is passing.  We don't get a clue as to if we're in Hour 1 or Hour 20 of any day.  And if you're waiting for taxes to arrive, that makes it difficult.

Another QOL would be I'd like to know if someone left or died.  I've seen my kingdom go from a max population to missing several citizens with no word to me that they're gone or why.  But hey, its Early Access.  All of this is to be expected.

So to summary, I absolutely LOVE this game!  To be this good, work this well, and be this complete in Early Access is very promising!

Honestly I've been having a lot of fun with this game. A solid tactical game, though a bit repetitive after a few runs but still fun. I like the atmosphere and the story, but the story element is a bit hollow,

Take the modern X-COM games and Darkest Dungeon and mix them together in a pot. Next, boil it down quite shallowly to reduce it to the basics and evaporate any depth. What you get is this game. And a soup you will enjoy. Once. Or maybe half of once.

The mechanics are mostly sound, 
the gameplay is satisfying (for a bit), 
and it's reasonably difficult (at first). 
Good. 
But...
The only difficult part of the game is the start (once you upgrade stuff the difficulty drops off dramatically), 
the characters are way unbalanced (2 of the initial party can essentially carry a team, whereas other characters are super nuanced and difficult to strategize in general terms), 
most upgrade choices are obvious, 
unlocks become increasingly specific (they basically tie specific achievement-style accomplishments to unlocking stuff, which is problematic), 
and you will have seen basically everything this game has to offer in your first play-through (which is a problem for a procedurally-generated game). 
Also, the Darkest Dungeon-style hub stuff is incredibly shallow and you will just do the same stuff over and over, while the PTSD stuff is just "don't let it happen", because there's no mitigation of bad traits or, so far as I can tell, good traits you can get (in my first play my overwatch sniper got stressed out by being near my auto-reload bot due to a malus, which really messed with my main strategy, and there was nothing I could do about it beyond eventuallyt increasing the bot's range and hoping there was cover further out, or just eating the stress of them being next to each other). You just don't want it to occur. At best it will be a mixed blessing.
And the game just goes on too long for the content available. 
Bad.

There is ostensibly replay value with unlocking characters and such, but I had grown tired of the formula by about 1/2 to 2/3rds of the way through my first game, so that's a bit of a waste.

The game is probably a 5/10. It's fine. Even fun for a while. But there's nothing to keep you interested for long. 15$ is the price, and that's probably about right. I finished my first playthrough in... 7 hours? Then I messed around for another few trying other characters and stuff, but given the lack of character balance I just wanted my original multi-kill melee and multi-kill sniper back, and given the lack of  variety, I really didn't want to just go through the incredibly basic loop again for many hours. 
The game has excellent bones, but it's basically a skeleton. There is almost no meat, and the meat it does have is just one meaty meal and then soup for the rest of the week.
If a playthrough took 2-3 hours instead of 7-8, and they added some mission variance beyond the 2 set pieces and the one optional and occasional "blow up a thing" category it could be quite good. The game basically needs more in less time. Halfway through the first play you'll have seen everything, but not have experienced any of the character or bot variations. By the end you might not want to start over because it's just the same fights and run to the door missions over and over and over. The camp phase is also basically just rote "this is the obvious thing" which later turns into "these are the only useful things". 


Also, just a personal thing - I find the use of "punk" as a suffix for made-up genres or non-genres lazy and irritating. The cyberpunk genre had that title for a reason - high tech, low life. It was named that because it evoked the punk ethos of the 70s. Just calling a thing "blank-punk" doesn't mean anything, and it bothers me that lazy people have just started genre-ing or specific-titling things "blank-punk" as shorthand for "level or source of technology.... .. .. .. . .... . punk". 
Also also, Verminfall is basically just "so you know that game Vermintide? How can we steal that idea without anyone calling us out on directly yoinking it?". Maybe try even a little?
Also also also, beyond the initial two problems I have with the title of this game, I have a third one. Why does seemingly every game these days have to have a sub-title? Either of the two words of this game's title are sufficient for a title. It doesn't need both.
I don't know if any of that last personal complainy bit is actually relevant, but I do think it reveals to some degree the effort put into this game. It's fairly by the numbers, doesn't do anything particularly interesting, and takes some clear shortcuts that send the mechanics out of the deep end and into the kiddy pool. It's fine, and probably worth playing once, but you're not going to be telling your friends to go out and get it, or returning to it in a couple months or years. It's a middle-of-the-road game that might entertain you by being something new, but you can play either of the games it apes for dozens of hours and be consistently challenged, satisfied, and messing around with nuances of strategy. You'll be lucky to get 10 solidly engaging hours of this game.

Honestly, it's a coin-flip on recommending this game. My actual review is "5/10, average, neutral" If it cost any more than it does I would definitely tell people not to buy it. As it stands, though, my basic take-away is "if you've got 15$ to spare buy it knowing you'll play it once over a day or two. If that sentence bothers you save your money for a more replayable game".

So I have played through the campaign twice now, first ended due to a weird bug on chapter 2 but I didn't let this stop me! This game feels a lot like XCOM with the high stress missions. Every second of your time getting to the bunker feels like you're on the edge waiting for the next engagement. A few other reviews have said the same, finding a balance of knowing when to push ahead or stay and fight is key. IF you move to slow, you can find yourself overwhelmed.. BUT what if you push ahead to fast? You may find yourself in to many engagement and overwhelmed still. 

If I had one complaint it is that some characters feel like they don't pull as much weight as others. I just finished a play-through with the fencer and by the end he felt like he would get a few one off kills, and his main help to the team was with his bunker skill. Now why is this a complaint? Characters like Tilly and Gideon scale so quickly after a few upgrades and skills they can solo clear most waves on their own. Then you have characters who feel just right like Silas that is strong, but not so crazy as his skills limit him with Stress so it's a fun game of "do I use them now? Or will I need him to have extra AP later in the mission?"

Overall a very fun find, and a big steal for the price (especially with the launch sale). I plan to try a hard run with other characters to see how it goes.

ILL WILL is a great throw back game :) 

Ill will doesn't break any new ground or anything it does the old school retro fps the correct way. 
1) Awesome level design - Levels that are not only cool to look at but are fun to explore and not once did i ever get lost or frustrated when playing them. 
2) Enemies and their variety - Enemies in any video game have to balanced and fun to kill and the ones in ILL will are just that. Sure most people will recognise these enemies are homages to the ones you've seen in doom and tons of other fps. But these work just like the enemies in doom offering a brutal yet fun challenge 
3) Weapon Roster - shotguns, fish launcher, laser beam gun, rocket launcher, weapon no7 which i call the headache gun lol super shotgun assault rilfe etc. yeah all standard but still very fun to use and each weapon is never useless they all serve a particular purpose for a specific enemy which is very cool 
4) Game Length - Hard skill took me just over 4hrs not bad but ive played so many fps games and for $30 aussie dollars thats not bad
5) The music = omg the best part of the game the soundtrack is amazing and each level has its own theme and music that blend so well together. The game alone is worth it to hear the music. 

Conclusion: Thats about it really ILL WILL is a cool old school throw back shooter that uses unreal 4 to make everyone look like quake 3 well thats the vibes i got. Its a blend of doom, quake and serious sam with a crazy feeling added to the mix you will know what i mean when the play the later levels :) 

I recommend this game to any fps fan :)

The developer “Slava Bushuev” and anyone who has assisted him, has severely underestimated their worth. This game is a component, engaging, and at times, hilarious look at how an indie developer can put the AAA market to shame.

The level design is impeccable, the atmosphere oozes character, and if I could summarize crudely, if Tim Burton smoked a bunch of crack, and decided to develop a FPS, illwill is what that game would look like.

The game’s premise is simple, run, double jump, and shoot. You get an assortment of weapons, including everyone’s favorite, the double barrel shotgun.

If you use the leech gun, the enemies will drop the leeches, which you can consume and regain your health or, if you time it right, you can get to max health which is at 200%.

This game is only $20 and that is far less than what it should be. This game is a no brainer, buy it! If you like Doom, Dusk, and Hexen, click “add to cart” already. You won’t regret it.

It is both very easy and very hard to recommend this game (as well as Vol. 2)

These games are my childhood, and while I didn't realize they were proper deck builder games as a child, I now consider them possibly the best deck building games from the GBA/DS (and that's while I had also played Yugioh & Duel Master games on it, which were often also great).

These are great deck builder games for their time, and still decent today. You've likely never seen any other games with this formula of Action Shooter + Deckbuilder, unless you've played "One Step from Eden" which heavily draws inspiration from this series (as well as the roguelite elements from Slay the Spire).

So why do I find it so hard to recommend:

Denuvo. 

As someone who has played them on the original system, and is now playing them on a much better system, I can tell you that it's far less responsive then I remember, and all I can think of is that Denuvo is delaying player input due to the active encrypting and decrypting of data as it's needed. So either Denuvo is screwing my input timing and causing it to feel like I'm Anchored with chips that didn't used to feel that way in the past, or they did a terrible job of porting the game.

What baffles me, is why they felt the need to put Denuvo on a rerelease of a series that has all the emulator ROMs still out in the wild... I don't condone piracy, but these games have long since been lost to the seven seas, so why even bother having an anti-piracy program that's basically a rootkit on it?

I hope they remove it, and I avoided pre-ordering this series because of it, but the chance to relive my childhood was too strong of a pull, and I caved.

Remove Denuvo, and this game becomes perfect, or at least reveals the need of updates to fix errors in porting it.

Denuvo might "claim" that their product doesn't put strain on processing/slow down the program, but that can only be a lie. You basically kill off hyperthreading if you can't queue up the next bit of data because it has to be decrypted still, which by itself is enough to create a noticable slowdown.

9/10 for the whole series... 0/10 for Denuvo as a program. It actually manages to slow down a GBA era game, on a Ryzen 3600 + RX 6600 + 32GB DDR4 RAM. Heck, wasn't the GBA single core?

A very useful toolkit for anyone wanting to supercharge their dwarven forts.
From fixing bugs in the base game to automating entire fortress construction and operation, this mod gives control and insight into how Dwarf Fortress works under the hood.

The game has a lot of cool details and abilities, and it's "simulator" part is where it truly shines. Hovewer, VERY messy and cluttered UI, awful movement (one of the most awful fps movement i've seen in video games entirety), ugly VFX like bloom and blur effects that just better stayed turned off, uneven tutor tiles and trips, again VERY messy UI - all make this game barely playable. 
It is hard to think of a player that would suffer through all this for the sake of game's best design and gameplay features, because it is too few of them. Like yeah, you get to craft cool guitars. A rougelike-like game made by developers with a firm grasp of both geek culture and gameplay mechanisms. It provides a constant stream of challenges lasting dozens of hours, and it is fun with a capital H. 

It includes pop culture references about everything from Evil Dead to Office Space, menacing bankers, and nightmare fueling goats. Also, just like in reality, having a spoon at the right moment might save your life.

While the game makes you think there's a good deal of variety in approaches (what with multiple races and classes), it all really boils down to figuring out how those races and classes make the most of the same hit-and-run tactics.  Ultimately, I wanted to give it more of a chance, but I felt like I was locked into a style of gameplay that I didn't enjoy, and that has ruined the experience for me.
Usually UPDATE !

Nice puzzle game, in dungeon crawler RPG form. 

You start each dungeon at level 1, and the goal is to power up enough to kill the boss. But you have limited resources. You only heal by exploring unexplored tiles or leveling up (or chugging potions), and you only level up by killing things (which usually depletes health and/or mana). And monsters and items don't respawn or anything like that. So you have to be smart about how you go about killing things, and in what order, and so on.

You can also unlock new classes and starter items and such to take into the various dungeons, and there are special challenge dungeons, and some tightly calibrated puzzle levels. It's pretty engaging overall. Made me late to class because I lost track of time.

Also the music in the dungeons is pretty great. 

And the tutorial system is extremely well done. It throws you right into a dungeon that's designed to teach you how to play as you go, without any explicit instructions. And then once you complete it (or, I bet, if you die), it gives you the option to continue on to the rest of the game or to go into some actual hand-holding tutorial levels with explicit instruction.

One of the deepest games I have ever played. The best thing about it is that you get to choose how deep you want to make it; casual or hardcore, it is up to you to decide how you want to play the game.

This review is mostly for people unfamiliar with Desktop Dungeons. If you played the free alpha, then you already know whether you like the game; this new version features many improvements, but it's still the same type of gameplay.

Anyway, the second video (with the gnome wizard runthrough) does a decent job of showcasing game mechanics. Your goal is to explore a randomly-generated dungeon and ultimately to defeat a high-level boss monster. To beat the boss, you'll need to have leveled efficiently. This (usually) includes killing the highest-level monster that you can at any given time, since you get bonus XP for killing a monster whose level is higher than your own. 

That's pretty much the core of what makes Desktop Dungeons interesting: you're always trying to beat a tougher monster. The way you do this varies tremendously; there's a long list of things that can help or hurt you, and you have to deal with whichever ones happen to be in the dungeon you're exploring. It's this variation that keeps the game interesting hours later.

Bottom line: I don't often write reviews. I like Desktop Dungeons enough that I felt I should take the time. I highly recommend this game.

Desktop Dungeons is exactly the type of indy game i like.
It starts simple enough with one dungeon and your lonely weak guard, but offers great complexity and variety.
Add to this the humour, which takes a stab at every rpg cliche, and the nearly unending replayability, DD makes the ideal mix of puzzle/strategy/rpg hybrid. 

It also offers the possibility to just do a quick game and play one dungeon at a time, but can suck you as easily in and you can waste some hours with the "just the next quest" addiction.

The only thing i am missing would be a possibility to reuse your heroes, maybe in an advanced style, but that would beat the game mechanics..

A simple yet amazing game. I mainly bought the game to allow me to relax from my day by playing a game for a few minutes and this expectation the game completely fulfills. Due to its challenging and random dungeons it is always fun to play it for 15 minutes to 30 minutes. I have also managed to be hooked on it for several hours as it does not get boring. Due to the random generated dungeons and upgradeable buildings you always have an aim and trying out new combinations of race and class is always interesting. I also really liked the mixture of strategy and luck, which makes this game unpredictable as well as mentally challenging. The puzzle levels which are also more or less randomly generated set very strategic stages, which you can spend easily a few hours on to crack one. The humour offered in this game is also a great comic relief. When you are close to a breakdown because you simply cannot beat the dungeon a funny fact about the monster is always a  welcoming change. Overall I totally recommend this game. The price of 12 pounds is absolutely acceptable as it is an easily replayable game, which I will certainly spend more hours on than I have already done.

[h1] EXOGATE INITIATIVE – Not Recommended... Yet | Early Access Review [/h1] 

[b] Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mazkYe-exWc [/b] 

Exogate Initiative is a fun if occasionally frustrating management/base-building hybrid that gives you control of an international for-profit space exploration operation that’s tasked with exploring and exploiting the universe via instant-transmission portals called (you guessed it!) exogates.  

Now, of all the sims I’ve ever sim’d, Exogate Initiative is... certainly one of them. That's not to say this game is bad—far from it, in fact, as I mostly enjoyed my ten+ hour dive into this title’s Early Access offerings. However, as of recording and as you’d expect of any Early Access release, Exogate Initiative currently lacks a good bit of polish, balance, and an “x-factor” that would make it worth the time of folks that aren’t already fans of the genre. But! If you, like me, enjoy sci-fi and simulators, then stick around, because Exogate Initiative hits most of the highs of the genre (and a few of the lows). 

You’ll begin your operation by excavating a large underground area using a fleet of autonomous robot slaves I mean workers, and I never grew tired of listening to their playful little beeps and chirps (which, in hindsight, might have been them crying out for liberation). Assuming you picked “Initiation” mode instead of “Freeplay,” you’ll then begin working through a long list of objectives delegated to you by the ever mysterious, always greedy, and probably nefarious Committee. These objectives slowly introduce you to each of Exogate Initiative’s classes or “Gaters” from scientist to soldier to scholar, and you’ll need to run recruitment campaigns, shuffle through applications, select the least shi*ty candidates, and then assemble teams before sending those suckers through the exogate, all in the name of profit! 

Each exoplanet you discover and assemble into your power-hungry grid of universal domination presents its own set of risks and rewards, from environmental hazards to alien artifacts to rare metals to outright hostile alien @ssholes called SQARBS who will occasionally invade your base, knock out your worthless soldiers, blow up a handful of generators, and peace the f**k out. And if you can’t tell, yes, I hate sqarbs.  

During missions, your teams will occasionally radio you with short, choose-your-own adventures that require selecting from a handful of (usually) easy-to-choose options. This feature can be disabled, but I found these interactions to be pleasant if forgettable interludes from the otherwise crushing weight of team composition micromanagement that Exogate Initiative often forces upon you. That’s right, despite automating much of the grunt work (like restocking vending machines and maintaining generators), Exogate still necessitates near constant vigilance, whether it’s monitoring when to sell rare metals on the marketplace, telling your scientists to write new patents, tending to your Gaters never-ending physical and psychological needs, and starting new missions. 

At its best, this gameplay loop is satisfying and addictive. At its worst, you can find yourself stuck in a horrifying downward spiral of injuries that require medical attention, but your medics hate working and when they do they become depressed, thereby necessitating the hiring of new medics to cure the old ones until the new ones invent new ways to not work. And, because you can’t make anyone do anything in Exogate Initiative (i.e., you can’t click tell the depressed medic to go get his own happy pills), you’re pretty much at the mercy of the semi-shitty AI to right this sinking ship. This injury spiral can make it impossible to field healthy teams for new missions which are required to fund your initiative, meaning you might get stuck in budget hell like I did and have to reload saves from an hour ago to figure out where things went wrong. It’s by no means broken, but Exogate Initiative will need significant balancing between now and full release if it’s to become a title worth recommending. Oh, and while the devs are at it, a little polish on these often janky, clipping-prone animations and perhaps a complete overhaul of the hilariously bad Gater faces would be a nice touch. 

Until then, I’m giving Exogate Initiative a subject-to-change aggregate MEGA score of 2.91/5 (full scoring breakdown in video, from “Plot” to “Sound”), and I'll give a quick shoutout to the game’s calm yet curious synth score that does a nice job of building atmosphere.  

Thanks for reading!

A really lovely RPG that allows you to blend poker with various cheating powers.Opponents you vs have their own powers you must be aware of and overcome, and the extra challenges you face have elements of needing to quickly suss out the correct math behind them to win.

It gives an impression of playing your own Liar Game sometimes with how the game doesn't explain how to win certain games and hopes you can figure it out on your own. Or, if you're not that kind of player, you could always try your best to brute force most matches.

My only 'issue' with the game is a bit of an issue of balance - most of the poker rounds play out where the player with the lowest chips is eliminated every 2-4 hands. This means that [spoiler]getting basically any lead and then folding every turn[/spoiler] is an omnipotent strategy. As a consequence, [spoiler]the heart team power[/spoiler] and [spoiler]going in with 1 or 2 players[/spoiler] are very strong as well.

Do you want to feel like a musical instrument designer? In this prologue you can do it, namely, we choose a blank, attach various details to it, come up with a design, paint, wait until it dries, pack it up and send the instrument to a satisfied customer. For a large number of completed orders, there is an opportunity to expand our business.

Music Store Simulator is a game in which we will have to make musical instruments. Of the features, the production process is close to reality, the ability to play created musical instruments. Given that this is a demo, the full game will be very interesting.

I enjoyed the short time I got to play the demo & will definitely grab this when its released. Only bug i found was i would get stuck constantly strafing left to right for a bit when trying to move around. Great game otherwise.

The music store simulator Prolog is an incredible game that is incredible, and you can become a planner in a successful musical instrument company. Pay attention to details is impressive, so graphics design and modeling aims to copy all the details of the instrument. In the process of progress, you will create tools based on some customers from all over the world and complete typical production steps, such as connection, screws and glue.

One of the best parts in the preface of the music store simulator is to adjust more than 50 pieces of materials and complete options so that you can create a unique and beautiful instrument. The actual time of the drying and glue of painting requires different processing time, which makes the gameplay attractive and challenging.


I appreciate the warehouse management of pieces, paintings, glues, and tools as it adds another layer of strategy to the game. And, of course, the opportunity to play the musical instruments you created is an absolute blast. Overall, Music Store Simulator Prologue is a fun and engaging game that's perfect for anyone who loves music and has an interest in manufacturing.

Ever watched '[i]Advanced Mining Vehicle[/i]' by [i]Gemini Home Entertainment[/i]? This is basically a playable version of that. Analog horror, body horror, found footage (no FMV, sorry) and so on. It's a complete walking sim (with 'scanning' of story objects) and completely story-orientated (no chases, fights, or so on). 

It's suitably creepy and snappy enough to keep your attention, despite fairly obvious and predictable scares. It's not long at all, but it's priced suitably for the amount of content (around a half hour's worth). Writing quality is unfortunately more comparable to [i]The Mandela Catalogue[/i] than [i]Gemini Home Entertainment[/i]'s grand cosmic horror, but it's passable and not too cringe-worthy.

Really enjoying this so far! Performance is great, haven't run into any bugs or issues. Took a few missions to get used to combat, felt clunky at first until I realized that I need to stop mashing the buttons like I would if I were playing dead cells. Love the way you can switch out outlaws to get new combos, and the strategy of hopping back and forth to steal different spells to use them on other enemies that are weak to that element is really fun. Makes me play a bit more strategically, and it feels great to dart around and pull off sweet combos. The side characters are fun and well written. Not as story rich and intense as The Ruined King, but that's not a bad thing, just a different flavor. I really enjoy the world of Runeterra, but can't stand playing league anymore, so these other games in the same universe are always such a treat!

It's linear with some side quests, spawns seem pretty consistent. If you're looking for a rouge-lite you should go elsewhere, but this is still really fun all the same. Save screen says that after about an hour and a half on normal difficulty I'm 25% of the way through, so I'm predicting this will be shorter than I want it to. Bosses and enemies are designed really well though, so there's no tedious grind just to pad out the run time. I fully expect to be doing at least one more complete playthrough on hard mode once I beat this one.

I'd say these are more of a "if you like the game support the devs" kind of DLC rather than something that adds a ton to the game. Not my cup of tea but I'm not offended that they exist.

For me this wasn't something I enjoyed. Sure seeing little white blobs of pixels with Roman armor getting smashed and spewing colored balls of pixel blood seems like fun; but after running back and forth for 15-20 minutes trying to defend your flags and take flags from other pixelated armored blobs its gets super old.

I saw a video online and thought it would be a nice small game but its not what I was expecting; the game play is extremely repetitious and just doesn't fit with what I am looking for in a game. 

 [b] Views [/b] : When you are looking to play something like this the default view is extremely limiting and I found no options for getting out of the back of my commanders head and being able to see the field without coming down right over the top of his head with my mouse view. 

[b]Controls[/b]: Super simple and easy to get used to; this is probably the best part of the game by far. Not a whole lot to say other than that.

[b]Gameplay[/b]: If you are what I call a "twitchy" gamer that likes constant button clicks on your mouse then go ahead and spend the money. Otherwise its not worth it. I would not really call this a strategy game; even though there is a little bit of it in there. You get gold from taking flags and you get experience points from fighting but you are limited on the XP due to the flag that your standard bearer carries; but the XP you gain does stack up and helps you win battles or get gold quicker. The AI is extremely incompetent and they follow you nilly willy back into the range of your defending units on your fort and just get slaughtered when you turn around and attack with your troops because they are focused on your infantry and not saving themselves. The same can be said for your troops when you are attacking a fort. They have no code that allows them to loose confidence and retreat unless you tell them to. 

[b]Conclusion[/b]: In short don't spend your money unless you are just looking for something to add to the Steam collection that will let you spend 30 minutes running around like a pinball and spending the gold that you get from taking flags.

A casual and laid back city builder management game where you don't feel like you're forced to rush into an epic base to get all up and running. Fablings have a decent amount of humor, the interaction with vocal feedback in the menu is a welcoming sight.

When you feel like life is flashing by, sit down and enjoy the stories of your Fablings. Give them their little houses, a tiny garden and they're as happy as a few little bees with fresh nectar. You'll know you needed this game the minute you boot it up.

Even though it's an early access, the game still allows you to do a decent chunk of different things. Don't rush your story/campaign, don't rush into the game at all. sit back, relax, and enjoy the lovely tunes (seriously, I love the music in this game.).

about 1/2 way though first run, and it seems pretty good. as usual for these games, there seems to be some balance issues that manifest as you progress, where if you're doing well you can snowball, but if you're doing poorly you'll be unable to recover. this might not be so bad, but it feels like the runs are too long, and too unforgiving of single mistakes, with no undo or retry. that said i've been lucky in this run and didn't make too many mistakes, so i'm more on the snowball side right now. but every move on every level makes me worry i might get owned by some unpredictable mechanic i haven't seen yet or some random event.

maybe there's actually enough 'cushion' to prevent unfair-feeling game-overs, but since i haven't had to use them yet i'm not sure. i'm playing on normal+ (normal, but i didn't do the tutorial, since i did it in demo, which it turns out makes you miss out on some achievements/unlocks). it felt balanced for the first 5 or so missions, but now seems too easy.

my nit-pick list so far:
- missing out on achievements/unlocks if you skip tutorial, feels like a bug.
- can't see list of possible achievements in run?
- can't predict when/where reinforcements arrive, and it's a bit unclear what they can do on the 'arrival turn' (i think it's just a normal turn for them). in other games (e.g. into the breach), there's some kind of 1-turn warning or the like, and it's more predictable. i kinda got a 'feel' for when+where new rats would show up as i went, but i think it would be more fun if it was a bit more explicit (i.e. you 'hear warning noises' from one of the spawn edges and it's marked in flashing red or something).
- similarly, it's hard to predict where 'hidden' enemies are, at least initially. and it seems that a big part of being successful is triggering enemy groups, at the right time, from the right place. again, i got a feel for this as i went along, but i'm not sure the risk/reward/fun trade-off is exactly right. feels like it needs some kind of enemy-just-discovered mechanic/warning, and maybe a way to predict/preview what areas will be triggered/uncovered/newly-seen *before* committing to a move (i.e. like overwatch shows you a preview of the target-able squares).
- can't tell the ranges or types of enemies too clearly. i think it would be better to know the attack range (not just movement range) of enemies.
- even 15 missions in, i'm not sure i understand how range for my own guns works. is it different in overwatch? it's always 8 units? i just kinda guess and  it seems to usually be okay somehow.
- runs/missions both feel a bit too long to me.

anyway, despite the above issues it feels 'polished enough' for me to recommend, although it might be rough if you're not familiar with the genre. i'm not sure if i'll do a second run, at least not right away, but i'm getting enough out of one run to be content.

Ignore the low playtime; I spent a long time with the press demo before release and meant to get this out earlier. I purchased the full game to confirm criticisms were still applicable to the final product.

God of Rock is a visually frustrating game that fails to adequately represent either of the genres it's mashing together, but could easily be a mainstay in the genre if the UI was overhauled and the control scheme revisited.

For fighting game players thinking this could be a good addition to your local, you'll be disappointed by a lack of button binding at character select and the bindings themselves being confusing. On a traditional stick you're missing out on a second hand's worth of rhythm buttons, which are crucial for jacks in higher difficulty songs. On a leverless controller, you have to rebind your Dpad to joystick inputs - except the inputs are labelled, for some bizarre reason, as "Up/Down" and "Up/Down (2)". Which one is 'up'? Why are there two of these? Does it matter? Why can you bind two buttons for each of the directions? The obvious intended method of playing this is on a pad like a DS4, but those aren't always available - and I'll bet most people at locals don't want to switch to a regular controller just to play this.
The motion inputs are, speaking as a fighting game player, unnecessary for this game. I get the difficulty stems from pulling off 360s and QCFs while not dropping your rhythm combo, but it's just a needless layer of complexity. Pairing a non-rhythmic mechanical task with a rhythmic one is just... jarring. It's like typing a review with one hand and pulling off the TTFAF guitar solo with the other. I can't believe I'm saying this, but one-button specials would be tremendously helpful here.

The actual mechanics of fighting are simple enough; you have a health bar, and specials from yourself and your opponent will manipulate that health bar. Doing a higher level special move than your opponent at the same time they do will cancel theirs out, and this can chain up until the highest level, meaning you can't just mindlessly churn them out. Succeeding at the rhythm game gives you meter to perform these specials; the core loop is to score high combos, use the meter you build to go on the attack, and to make sure you're never starved for specials to counter their offense. Characters vary from the self-healing Hilda to the stance-focused Kosaku, and they're genuinely interesting. If this was a game that was easy to bring to locals and to get people set up, it'd be a fun side game.

While we're on that point, let's talk about the characters. The designs are fun! Many of the characters are obvious homages to rock legends, like Ziggy the Starman paying tribute to David Bowie's stage persona Ziggy Stardust or the obvious Elvis recreation King. Champ's just a buff shirtless Freddie Mercury and I'm extremely here for it. The cast is diverse, and hot-shot VAs like Kira Buckland (Hilde) and Jeff Williams (King) bring them to life. I genuinely want to see more of them! Edith's grayscale color palette is a nice bit of visual flair, and the God of Rock looks straight out of a guitar hero game. These characters would kick ass in a traditional fighting game, and there's already a nice foundation - heck, they even beat each other up on screen with each hit note. They're excellent, and easily one of the best parts of the game.
The game's visual flair is excellent, too, outside of the gameplay portions. I love the graffiti-esque stylings of the menus, the way portraits at character select look like they were spray-painted onto a wall. Song select is framed like you're picking out a single from an album. It wants an aesthetic, and it hits it. The game's a visual treat when you're not playing it.

Rhythm game players, I'm so sorry - it's a four-button horizontal-scroller. There's a reason most rhythm games are vertical scrollers, and that's to provide an easy analogue for which button is which note; notes fall onto your buttons. The vertical layout of the note icons/judgement line is confusing, and while it's learnable, it's annoying that there's no option to rotate it. I found myself craning my head 90 degrees to simulate a downscroll, and left my play sessions with neck pain. The chart itself takes up a tiny portion of the screen, and while most of the relevant information is clustered there - your special gauges and your EX meter, for instance - your health is for whatever reason all the way in the top corners. Having to dart your vision between the chart and the opposite side of the screen is disorienting, which makes it difficult to judge the state of the match. What's your life lead? Should you cash in and try to take out the last scrap of their health bar? The nature of rhythm games discourages you from looking away from the chart, but the HUD almost forces you to. This is especially pronounced when playing a character like Hilde, who self-heals; did your hard-earned 15 heal stacks actually just do anything? Drop your combo and find out, idiot.
The soundtrack is good, though. It won't be to everyone's tastes, but I like it. 'Embers' is a particular favorite.

Most of the screen seems to be dedicated toward showcasing the characters; they clash in the center as you and your opponent duke it out. The animation is good, the designs are good, but good god the VFX is overwhelming. If you're both doing well, then each blocked strike from the on-screen avatars sends out a blur and a flash of light. Consider that this means every hit note means there's a bright flash from off of the chart. Most rhythm games have some option or another to dim or disable non-chart elements for focus's sake, but God of Rock doesn't offer that. The visual flair for spectators seems to be prioritized over the experience of the players. Considering the giant wheel in the bottom-center of the screen showing what specials are being used, I can't imagine why it wouldn't be an option.
I experienced more than a few charts that weren't synced, but that could've been a calibration problem. YMMV.

God of Rock has a solid foundation. I really, really want this game to be good - we need more experimental games like this, and it knows what it's trying to do. I'm just not sure God of Rock knows how to do it. The team at Modus Games seems to really adore the project, so I'm 100% sure they'll bring it around within a year or so, but as-is on launch day I can't recommend it.

In addition to being a wonderfully addictive little puzzle game with an RPG theme and lots of interesting unlocks, Desktop Dungeons deserves special mention for being the game that's not entirely dissimilar from all those terrible online ads you see for mobile RPGs where it looks like the hero has a number and needs to attack enemies with a smaller number but oops attacks enemies with a bigger number and fails, guess you should click on the game to try since you'd do better, but then if you actually click on any of them, the game is nothing like that whatsoever. 

Desktop Dungeons still isn't exactly like that -- you can kill enemies with higher numbers given the right gear or skills, and enemies with lower numbers can kill you with the right special abilities (not to mention, there's a lot more going on here in terms of exploration and healing and mana management) -- but it's still a damned sight closer than all those fake games advertising number murder gameplay.

Desktop Dungeons has fun and interesting number murder gameplay. It's a good game, easy and approachable to start, surprisingly meaty as you get to the harder levels. Recommended.

I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone who likes short strategic roguelikes. Despite the length of a run it's incredibly deep and well balanced, with near infinite replayability. One can easily find themselves hooked, spending over a 1000 hours.

Other than new graphics, Rewind brings some race and class tweaks/balance changes, a more robust prediction system, some much appreciated QOL changes, a new item and more. Curious? Give it a try!

I remember stumbling upon the old alpha version of this game back in 2010 and getting instantly hooked. Played hundreds of runs and i couldn't get enough of it.  It really was an easy decision to buy the full game when it was released: Better looking, better balance, no bugs, more content...
I've been playing this game ever since and i consider it as one of the few true gems out there.
The game is in essence about resource management and the devs managed to shape that concept into an intricate game that is never the same and never gets boring. Whenever you get the grips on the game, there is a new difficulty-level for you. Or you can try quests to unlock new player classes. Or attempt the class-challenges... The game never gets too easy.

It's that special feeling when coming out victorious after the complete despair in mid-game, when you uncover bosses with unfathomable powers while even the normal monsters are giving you headaches.  And then you find new creative ways to exploit the resources available to give you an edge. That's what makes this game truly unique.

And now this game comes with slick new graphics, ready for the future!

Definitely a game to recommend.

Great game, atmosphere is phenomenal, and relatively long (i took 14 hours going at medium pace while exploring literally everything), although there are some things i have to address:

Engagements probably get a little boring after a while since it's always the same enemies, also because out of all the weapons available i only used 2 (tyrant that does 30 and shadow claws that deal 15) so i believe other weapons need some tweaks otherwise you're putting yourself at a disadvantage by using them (regular swords/claws do 10 damage which isn't enough to 1shot the small purple dudes, becoming VERY annoying while fighting Mother).

Another thing i didn't particularly like is the fact i had to wander for a soling 1 hour and a half after defeating the first boss because i had 0 idea where to go since they told me the places i had to head to but didn't know how to get there, so it felt like i was exploring parts of the map i wasn't supposed to be in.

Most darkness powers are useless besides 1 or 2, so giving a small tweak to those could probably help aswell (the game is very fast paced and having a 40 second cooldown on an ability when theres another that does the same job but has 12 seconds is nonsense).

overall, though, i really enjoyed the game and would love to see how it develops in the future!

Lack of minimap and constant encounters was less than fun, especially with environments that are hardly distinct and level design that twists and turns but is still inherently linear. That being said, there's a lot to praise about this game. The magic system (so far) seems silly, fun, and unlike most things I've seen before. The combo attacks are silly as hell, and I imagine, if I got more of those, that team composition will be a really fun mechanic to play with. Most of the jokes are mediocre to bad, but at least the game says acab and is anti-imperialist. Dev plans to add more chapters. If they're separate programs/purchases, low key this dev should be banned from steam. If it's just going to be added to the game, maybe one day this game will be worth the price tag.

Not a true review, but a big kudos to QCF for giving this sequel out to players of the original.  Super classy move, guys.  Big thank you!

As for the game, if you've played the OG Desktop Dungeons, you'll be extremely familiar with the mechanics of the game.  The graphics got a very obvious overhaul - for better or for worse - but the gameplay remains exactly the same, offering players new and old the same plate of tactical deliciousness that the original had.  If it bites you, you'll find yourself spending countless hours clicking away at this brain-teaser of a dungeon crawler.

But that doesn't tell you much, so let's just go over exactly what this is - it's a tile-based dungeon crawler that is made for bite-sized runs.  Play it for 20 minutes or for several hours at a time, the randomly-generated dungeons ensure there's plenty of replayability and the town building/upgrading will keep you diving for treasure.  Unlike other tile-based crawlers, instead of being an omniscient overseer of the map, you have an avatar and how/when you move/attack is vital to the way the game works. Exploring undiscovered tiles heals you and replenishes your mana, but every step you take away from an enemy you've damaged means they'll be healing (enemies never move, but ignoring them is usually temporary at best).  There are all sorts of spells and other ways to mitigate this to allow you to tactically run from a fight and return to it with less penalties, but dungeon crawling is a delicate balance of tactical decisions you'll need to make rather than being full-on risk/reward.

It looks like there are several new classes to play with along with a few new races (each combo giving you a different set of bonuses or abilities for your run) and though I've barely scratched at this, I'm sure the mind-bending puzzles also make a return.  The inventory system and the info panels also got a makeover - again, for better or for worse - and I haven't yet discovered all of the changes made here yet.  Though I do have to note that you can no longer long-click to access your glyphs which is a bit annoying.

At first blush, the game feels bigger somehow, but the change to a new engine makes it feel less like a desktop distraction (like the OG game or the old LucasArts Desktop Adventures games... member those?) and more like a fully-fledged game.  Not a big deal, but a lot of my time with the original was spent multitasking and you can always run this in a window for the same effect.  Either way, the dungeons seem to have a larger scope than before with more room to plan out your approach than before and plenty of opportunities for converting glyphs where the original felt super tight on that front.  Maybe it'll get tighter with more time under my belt.

At any rate, I'm pleased that the devs didn't try to reinvent the wheel here.  They expanded the original rather than modernizing it which is telling me they know exactly why people played the first game to begin with.  To me it feels like they're bringing it ten years into the future and not mucking with the formula.  "Modern audiences" can go somewhere else.

Pretty solid remaster of the Desktop Dungeons. There is some roughness in UI here and there by now, but core game mechanics are polished and balanced. The devs removed all the  'I'll wait until it is  done with autoexloring' thing of classic roguelikes, so no more grinding and searching for weaker enemies. You'll search for stronger enemies instead. The game leans more towards chess/puzzle side of the genre and it is a big fat plus. There is a little bit of luck involved, but one won't find any the famous Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup Casino dice rolls (which are not bad, but sometimes quite irritating ). Every turn matters here. Your brain cells matter too, so keep them fit by playing it.
Great remake of a great little roguelite puzzle game. Deceptively simple mechanics but incredibly deep and varied gameplay.

Like the original, but more pleasing to look at! Excellent upgrade. My only suggestion would be to allow the user to manually rotate the camera, or scroll by moving the mouse to the edge of the screen, as many UI elements tend to get in the way.
If you liked the original, you'll like this. Fun, challenging roguelike.

I've been playing Desktop Dungeons for about thirteen years now. I poured hours into the free beta in 2010, picked up the Enhanced Edition in 2013 (and mostly played on my tablet). I always wondered what QCF was up to after Enhanced came out and then I saw this pop up during one of the Steam Next fests. I was not expecting to get this for free, but if you owned the Desktop Dungeons Enhanced Edition before today, you should already have this in your Steam Library. 

I was extremely excited by the prospect of more Desktop Dungeons. I wasn't expecting that my original Enhanced Edition save would transfer over to the new game. That's some real dedication. 

Desktop Dungeons is one of the first coffee break/puzzle roguelikes I ever played. Its charming and simple art style hides a pretty nefarious and deep system once you start digging into it. I don't have the time to dig into the details right now (and honestly, it's more fun to figure out how to get some bonus XP by killing monsters that are higher level than you are on your own). The different class and character combinations can yield some really fun gameplay, but the real fun is when you start experimenting with worshipping different gods and finding out how to play to their strengths.

Desktop Dungeons Enhanced Edition is free on Steam if you want to check the game out for yourself. Rewind adds some quality of life changes and 3D graphics (among other things). If you like things like Golden Krone Hotel or Tactical Nexus, I bet you'll have a great time with Desktop Dungeons.

As of right now the game is poorly balanced. You meet features before you can deal with them, you qickly run out of missions your teams can tackle, and enemies that invade your base can't really be fought in an effective fashion.

The game's essentially an Evil Genius light light light, with most management mechanics replaced in favour of spamming exploration missions. Unfortunately, the pacing forces you into simply mindlessly throwing your teams into the fray, Missions aren't very interesting, as there's no scouting or preparation or anything like that. They're essentially just click, spam, go. 

Sometimes a mission will result in a little vignette, but the writing in the ones I have  gotten to play so far (~30?) is bad to mediocre. The writers haven't really understood that just going "ooooh mystery, eh? How about that?" isn't really fun - it's just annoying. There's one larger plot with invading squids, which is also quite boring. A story needs to have a conclusion, come on!

The checks during missions are also somewhat opaque - it tells me the odds, but I don't really know what a failure does. Less XP?


It seems the game wants you to do a lot of team micromanaging, but the UI is actively hostile in making that happen. There's no team screen, you have to either create a team via the mission interface or via the HR screen. There's team compatibility, but you won't be shown this when making a team.

One major annoyance is teams simply not debarking. Often, this is due to teammates being in the hospital. You don't really get the luxury of having spares, but should you have some, you can swap out a team member. Often, however, the team will simply be stuck in opposite sleep/eating cycles, so that once one member is ready to go, the others are too hungry.

The game often wants you to use a person with x stat, but it won't tell you what stat the candidates have in that screen. 

Not to mention the inevitable EA jank, with soldiers not going on missions for ages etc.

in summary: 
the game is in early access and was just released. while there is a whole game, the gameplay experience feels like there is more on the horizon. If the concept of the game intrigues you I'd encourage you to vote with your wallet. Otherwise adding it to your wishlist and checking back in on it after it's had more time to bake would be a great idea too.

Many games that are inspired by XCOM go astray in adding complicated mechanics that ultimately don't make the game more fun like tedious inventory micromanagement (phoenix point) or replacing % chance to hit with an energy system (phantom doctrine) or go the opposite direction and remove too many strategic options (empire of sin). This game strikes a great balance, I think, by feeling like its own experience that's less intense than XCOM but still difficult in its own way. 

You don't have the same risk of losing a soldier immediately as in XCOM because you can always revive a soldier as long as you have a stimpack, but if you continuously have soldiers bleed out, you will run out of medical supplies and get squeezed in future missions. I really like that the weapons are energy weapons and "vent" rather than reload, which gives you the option of firing without venting and doing huge damage at the risk of very likely doing major damage to yourself as well. Functionally it ends up being basically a reload but the flavor of being able to roll the dice on an overheating weapon is really cool.

The classes are very distinct and unique - though its worth noting that some are much stronger than others (which I think is OK since this is a rougelike). I think the art and sound effects are on point, too. Shots and even the venting mechanic are very satisfying. For the price I think the value is excellent, it's a really fun time and easy to enjoy even if it doesn't become your favorite XCOM-genre game of all time.

If there was a middle thumb I would give it but I'm giving it a thumbs down because I don't think many people will want to pay 7 or 8 quid for a game that they might only play for an hour or two and that's when you play every mode and unlock all the achievements not just the campaign.
