This game is simple in design, beautifully executed and graphically and musically quite stunning. While the game is fun to play, it is also quite easy.. 

I play quite a few games but wouldn't call myself a roguelike, twinstick or shoot em up expert by any means and was able to beat the final boss for the first time on my 4th run.

As you can guess, in my opinion the game is on the easy side and especially does not provide much challenge after you get the hang of the gameplay loop. The standard enemies are simple and alright. Bosses are quite easy, however they are "relatively" varied in their attacks and environment hazards. 

For its price I personally think it is a good value game if you have money to spare or are into the genre. This game however does not provide the complexity and/or depth alot of roguelike/roguelite fans look for nor does it provide endless hours of content. To be fair, at its current pricepoint this is hardly a issue worth arguing.

As a side note for the developer:
The game became uncompleteable on that first "succesful" run. When I beat the boss I suddenly lost all my remaining health, stayed alive and for some reason was able to go into the abyss without getting respawned, dying or completing the game, as a result I was forced to reset.  I sadly am unable to privide insight in what caused it.

Suffer the Night is a horror game that draws inspiration from quite a few horror sources. And manages to make some intriguing gameplay choices split into a few chapters.

+The chapter with Mr.Tops is very good. great ambience and if you play your cards wrong you will get jump scared i reckon.
+Loved the nods to various horror mediums (Babadook, C'thulu,Hellraiser) too name a few.
+Animations were really good for Mr.Tops as well. Likewise for voice acting.
+Pretty heavy on the puzzles after chapter 1. 

Now for some negatives

-So the biggest one i encountered was a hard lock on my save file. I couldn't progress after a certain point. I posted this in the bug report forum. 
-Tension kind of goes out the window after chapter 1. Not necessarily a bad thing. But temper your expectations.


Overall a nice little horror excursion, Made on UE4, very basic to look at. Really enjoyed seeing the various horror titles being integrated into the game whether it's art posters, or just inspiration from other mediums. Performed well no crashing, or lag. If you're looking for a short but sweet horror ride. Visit Mr.Tops today!

As a pinball fan, and owner of TPA (The Pinball Arcade), and FX3, here is a fairly in depth comparison. While I certainly enjoyed FX3 with its unique tables and creations, there is no question many were incredibly easy with the floaty physics of the balls. Tables like Doom, while very fun, were almost impossible to lose. When it came to the reproductions of classic tables such as Williams, it usually fell short of TPA by a margin. The physics always felt off, and while it made for a fun pinball game, it fell quite short of a pinball simulation. This new Pinball FX claims improved physics and graphics, not to mention Ray Tracing, which can be hard for some hardware, though it runs pretty smoothly on my laptop and its 2080 Super. So what is best?

[b]Physics[/b]

Since this is a selling point, I compared all three for feel, but to avoid falling into personal biases, I brought up actual video recordings on YouTube and used them as a reference. Frankly, FX is the winner here, and it shows up in the reactions of the ball, but also small things like falling through the hole in a slide on Arabian Nights. TPA is not far behind in some tables but not all. Curiously, TPA actually has some off-flippers and angles of flippers on some tables. I had no idea of this until observing the genuine video footage. So a win for FX overall. TPA seems to have a lighter incline on all the tables so it is hard to know exactly, and I always found TPA very solid overall.

[b]Graphics[/b]

This is going to come as a surprise but while FX has the potential to be the clear best, its graphics and lighting need serious tweaking. The table lights (using [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tY2pFjj1Phg]original Williams tables[/url] to compare) are overly bright, creating exaggerated shadows. Some tables have outright wrong colors such as Arabian Nights. The lights near the bumpers are white instead of the actual yellow, as well as those around the table. The overall result is a much colder color scheme than the real table. 
What about Ray Tracing? Frankly, it is a serious disappointment as implemented for now. Side-by-side screenshots with it on and off show that the only visible result is a sharp increase in contrast, so darker areas are darker, effectively making the lights brighter by comparison. However, multi-point shadows and reflections and light bouncing is non-existent. So all you really get with RT is a darker table with deeper shadows. At least with the simulated Williams tables.

[b]Variety[/b]

In terms of simulated tables of old, TPA has an overwhelming edge still, with many many classics such as Firepower I and II, High Speed, and others, but TPA is a dead end, and WYSISWYG. FX is clearly very much alive not only for original creations (I had a hoot with the Snoopy table), but new classics are also being added. I read another user complaining about a mistaken magnet in Addams, but I have not tried it and cannot comment.

[b]Perks[/b]

Much like its predecessor, FX has a ton of added effects, such as flying scores, special effects and more. These can all be tailored to taste so that your game experience, if using a classic table, will not be distracted by these. However, they are a nice touch, no arguments.

[b]Cost[/b]

This is a very personal thing, so I will refrain from passing judgement. If you had tables from FX3, then you get them at 50% off here. I don't know what the cost in the US is, as I live in Brazil, but the average for the tables or bundles has been between $3-6. YMMV.

[b]Verdict[/b]

Right now, it stands as the best overall pinball experience for new tables and pure physics, but there are definitely areas to improve such as fixing the RT so it actually does more than deepen shadows, as well as fix the colors of lights and the general brightness of them. This is the only serious complaint I have, but it detracts from the overall impression. 

4/5 for now, but should the above be handled, then I will gladly rectify this to a 5/5.

Confusingly, Pinball FX is newer than Pinball FX3. And disappointingly, my favorite tables from FX3 are not available in FX, not even if I want to pay for them again. While the UI is a little bit cleaner to navigate, I don't see enough of a graphics or gameplay difference to make it worth having both FX and FX3 installed, so I'll stick with the old version that still has all the DLC I paid for. If you're new to Pinball FX, it's a good game; there is just a lot of disincentive to upgrading for those who have already invested in their FX3 pinball table library.

It is a very well thought out game. The movement is unique, being able to fly through space, but also land on surfaces and move there too. They even give you a grappling hook, how cool is that? The guns feel surprisingly fluid, and firearms are a huge talking point. The guns feel heavy, but smooth and powerful. They all have very nice design and sound design behind them and it is impressive to see how far the team has come from the start of development in 2016. Time to kill is fast, but in this setting it seriously makes sense. This is not a black ops four sense of 'Faster gun kill faster'. It is a solid sense of shot placement and just learning the gun's characteristics. Sure, you can kill somebody from 150 meters away with the sniper in one shot, but you could score a kill with an assault rifle from 50 meters or kill someone less that 10 meters away with a well placed handgun round to the helmet. The guns are amazingly balanced, and even have a nice attachment system with well thought out drawbacks. And with the game only $25 right now, it is worth it to try it out. I promise you will have fun.

*yes, you can adjust the velocity of your projectiles through weapon attachments, it's wild

(being entirely honest, I do wish I could hit this one with a mixed review option because the aforementioned issues are very concerning, but I love the game enough that I'll put up with it for now)

This game definitely doesn't deserve it's mixed review. It's a pretty darn well made game that's held back by some clunkiness and QOL issues. Hunt the Night is a hardcore top down action rpg, imagine mixing the Legend of Zelda with Bloodborne's setting and Castlevania looking characters.  I won't beat around the bush, this game is tough as nails and you will die a lot, so if you're after a more casual romp, please turn around immediately. 

Combat is all right, it can be clunky and frustrating at times but it can also be exhilarating and very satisfying when you're weaving dashes in between melee attacks to then unload you guns onto the enemy before finishing it off with your dark magic, the bones are well structured, it just needed some more polish. Enemy variety could have also been better, especially since this game loves to throw you into wave gauntlets.

The game doesn't have a map, which can be annoying for some, who don't pay attention or talk to NPC's so they end up not knowing where to go next,  but there is an NPC in the game that will tell you which direction to go, so it's not really a big deal.  If anything Hunt the Night's biggest flaw is balance, which is probably the best flaw to have because it can be easily patched, the difficulty spike around mid game can be a bit too sadistic.

Overall Hunt the Night might not break any new grounds, but it melds together well tried formulas into an intriguing dark fantasy world filled with challenges to keep you coming back for more and conquer them once and for all. It has a few QOL and polish flaws here and there and I would say maybe wait for a balance patch down the line, but don't overlook this gem

THIS GAME IS A STEAL FOR A LITERAL DOLLAR

It's good to have something you can pick up and blast through in a short time.

I am a sucker for this kind of art style, reminds me of Ed McMillen, or Behemoth.
This game is a short, simple, shmup roguelike. Super fast paced, a quick burst of addicting adrenaline.
And highly polished! I can't believe it was made in such a short time frame.

Collect upgrades with every level as you blast your way through the adorable enemies with insanely satisfying sound design. The pop of the cannisters is good EVERY TIME. The day/night switch is neat too, you have to think about your upgrades because most have a good and a bad side, one for day, one for night. The screen will be crowded by the end,
but you will be extremely OP. The boss is still a bit of a challenge though.

Some other things I like:
The colors really pop.
I love the arcade machine aesthetic.
I like how fast and breezy a playthrough is, literal minutes.

Desktop Dungeons starts off you very simply. You click on squares you want to move to, click on enemies to attack them, click on glyphs to use them, enemies attack you only when you attack them, and explore to regenerate health and mana. Your ultimate goal is defeat the boss of each dungeon and the dungeons are relatively short. Just thirty minutes max for a dungeon if you take your time on some the harder ones. All this may deceive you into thinking Desktop Dungeons is a simple game. It is not. 

The difficulty curve in Desktop Dungeons is wonderfully done. At first the only mechanics you need to master are the ones I listed above. Then classes, kin, and various enemies are introduced that force you tackle them in a variety of ways. Some classes rely on glyphs to win and others struggle to use glyphs forcing you find alternative ways to win. Some enemies are nigh impervious to regular attacks and others attack back when you use magical attacks on them. The semi random nature of the game will force you into situations where you cannot use optimal combos to win. Sometimes you're playing a class that struggles to use magic against enemies that you need to attack with magic to kill. So after you master the basics of the game you then have to learn how to use the various classes optimally and what to do when you can't use them optimally. You get a feel for what enemies are easy in what situations and hard in others. You advance further into the game and suddenly you find dungeons and enemies where previous strategies don't work. Those enemies you could kill a few levels higher than you suddenly can't be killed that way anymore. You have to find out ever better ways of leveraging your bonuses. Finding ways to deal just a little more damage or take a little less so you can kill tougher enemies. You have to manage your resources even better. For someone brand new to the game each hurdle the game places in front of you can seem insurmountable at first glance. But the game does a fantastic job of pushing the player to be better without having them give up. All the simple systems in the game get combined in a wonderfully complex way that never feels impossible to understand because of how the game eases you into them. 

For people interested in the game but have never played it: make no mistake, this is very much a strategy/puzzle game. The later levels will require you to really sit down and use your brain to solve them. The game never goes so far as to require you to calculate stuff out in advance to win but it will require a fair amount of foresight instead of blindly doing whatever actions seem best at the time. 

For people who played or know about the original are checking out the remaster: there a great deal of small gameplay changes that all make the game better in my opinion. You can see if tiles have potions on them from the glow on adjacent tiles, the fighter class had a number of changes, and you can see enemies in the fog if you get close enough. These are just a few changes they made. The rewind feature is really nice. If the new perspective annoys you there is a button in the bottom left corner that gives you a full overview like in the original game. My only complaint is that the old artstyle is gone. The new 3d stuff is good but I adored the original art. 

Some last remarks for those who have read this far. The writing is very good and the humor in the game is very much in the same style as Terry Pratchet. The music is also great and very fitting for the feel of the game. My favorite track is Troll in A Minor if you want to look it up and give it a listen before buying the game. I should also mention that the devs were kind enough to give the remaster to everyone who bought the original game for free. A completely unnecessary gesture given how much work has gone into the remaster more than justifies the price. Although my opinion doesn't amount to much, I would like to finish by saying I think Desktop Dungeons is in the top 100 games ever made. I put it so low only because of how many amazing games have been made throughout history and not to say that Desktop Dungeons isn't THAT good. Every single part of the game is amazing well executed and the game's relative obscurity is mostly due to the genre's lack of popularity and not because the game has been found lacking.

Desktop Dungeon is a phenomenal puzzle dungeon crawler that truly tests your strategic thinking skills. The game's retro-style graphics are charming and give a nod to classic dungeon crawler games of the past, but the gameplay is anything but old-fashioned.

The game offers a unique blend of RPG-style mechanics and puzzle elements that requires you to carefully plan out each move, considering the strengths and weaknesses of your character and the enemies you're facing. As you progress through the game, you'll unlock new characters, items, and abilities that add even more depth to the gameplay.

One of the standout features of Desktop Dungeon is its accessibility. The game is designed to be played in short, bite-sized sessions, which makes it perfect for busy gamers who don't have a lot of time to sink into lengthy gaming sessions. Plus, the game's intuitive interface and helpful tutorial make it easy for players of all experience levels to jump right in and start playing.

Overall, I highly recommend Desktop Dungeon to any puzzle or RPG fan. It's a challenging, addictive game that will keep you coming back for more. Give it a try – you won't be disappointed!

For being early development, I have already clocked 8 hours and continue to add more. The game is extremely cute, easy to understand, and accessible for casual gamers. Due to the nature of it being in early development, it does lack content and has a couple bugs. A couple suggestions to make this game more enjoyable without over complicating it would be:

Content:
- multiplayer to trade with friends
- a cathedral (solely for the aesthetic purpose, could possibly boost happiness)
- being able to move a building without having to completely demolish it
- horses or carts to allow stockpilers to move resources more easily
- more decorations/having decorations improve happiness
- more events (such as the witch)
- a night cycle (could have unique events or limited jobs like a tavern?)
- being able to replant Bob
- a flower shop to use flowers and boost currency
- allowing the villagers to use the dice table (or at least see them interact with their environment)
- showing a range on storage such as the granary or stockpile (able to be toggled)
- being able to place decorations on top of pathing

Bugs of notice:
- the villagers consistently starve even when you have a surplus of food
- villagers constantly get stuck (this may be "where is my body," but I am not sure)
- the pigs cannot be moved or killed so you have to build around them
- certain buildings will not demolish (such as the condo)

Overall, this game is 100% worth your money. My friend and I have an hour/dollar rule in which a game is worth it's money if you play for the amount of hours you spent on the game ($1=1hour). I can easily see this game going over it's hour/dollar limit, as I have only had it for two days, clocked 8 hours, and it is still in early development.

Love the aspect of creating a kingdom and being able to interact with other kingdoms around the world! It's so awesome to be able to create relationships with other kingdoms for trade or war. The building in the game is amazing too, having different ranked villagers that have their own tasks and places to live and work while expanding and progressing the kingdom. 10/10 recommend if you like chill games that have a slight survival aspect to them.

It's a fun game overall. I wish you could move buildings or upgrade the peasant home into condos/townhouses instead of having to build both. It's kind of pain when you unlock a hospital well into the game, just to find that you don't have a plot large enough in the middle of your homes to actually have it cover the area needed. The first winter is fine, you get a secret santa gift when you don't have enough supplies. After that though, your villagers die off from starvation despite the fact that there is food available or die from sickness, despite the fact that there is a hospital in their area (and the hospital is only at 2 out of 8 patients). What's the deal? That's kind of annoying honestly. 

I  restarted my game after I unlocked the hospital on the first one and tried to deleted buildings to make room for the hospital (and rebuild the buildings somewhere else) and made a huge mess of things, out of almost 90 villagers I killed all but one from starvation... oops. I do like the game, but it is in early access and has huge progress to be made. I have maxed out all the available content within 8 hours (not all of that actively playing). There isn't a ton of content yet. I'm hoping it will get a lot better after they release more content. For now, I think I will wait until then to play again.

Lately, I have been paying quite a bit of attention to games with roguelite elements, and this game was a good experience in the genre. 
The goal of the game is to activate 4 machines on a random map, with an increasing wave of enemies appearing over time. 
The shooting controls follow the standard stablished for the genre, and the number of different builds is relatively high, but nothing extravagant like in Rogue Legacy, for example. 
The sound effects are good, and the music is OK. 
The first runs last 4 minutes until death, and after gaining more experience and upgrades, I was able to maintain around 12 minutes per run. The game is very dynamic and delivers an enjoyable gameplay experience. 
As it is in early access, I believe the game can only improve from this solid foundation. 

To the devs: I recommend paying attention to the menu and HUD, which don't stand out much but fulfill their basic function. I look forward to the updates and the game's release.

Fun free to play roguelike deckbuilder.

I love deckbuilding games and this was free, so I decided to try it out.  Game is easy to get into, and has a tutorial to explain the mechanics.  It plays like other deckbuilders, but has some unique aspects.  Instead of choosing a path, you are given card that represent enemies, shops, events, and treasure and have to assemble the path you want to take.  Each path ends with a miniboss and the third path ends in a boss fight.

You get two characters so far in the free version, one you start with and one you unlock.  Combat is well animated with pretty graphics.  Battles have you managing two different energies.  One for attacks and one for spells.  After beating an enemy you get an upgrade and about halfway through the second level, I was incredibly overpowered, and this snowballed to make the final level very easy.  The only issue was I had so many abilities that it would cause the game to lag each time I played a card, as it had to process all of the abilities triggered by the card.  This did lead to some lag spikes and once the game seemed to think I had ended my turn when I had not.

You can customize your character at the start by picking a god and zodiac sign.  These will made differences in your character, but I beat the game the first time I played it and I do not see a way to increase the difficulty.  This game could use that, because as it is, there is no reason to play again.  The game really should implement a scoring system so I could compete with my friends to see who can get a high score.

It is a free game with no restrictions on game play for those that want to try it out.  DLC currently is an extra character, so if you like deckbuilding games, there is no reason not to download it.

I received this for owning the original. This remaster is unfortunately inferior to the original because of the poor UI. Twisting the camera as the game zooms in seems like an artistic decision, but it's rather annoying in practice since there's no other way to turn the camera manually. If you zoom out, you can sort of see everything and the camera untwists itself, but the zoomed out 3D graphics just don't provide a great overview compared to the nice 2D art of the original.

If more is done to make it less of a chore and hard on my eyes to play this, I'll change my review. Though, even if this becomes a game I recommend later, it still might not be better than the original.

I have about 730 hrs in the original and also did a bunch of playtesting for this remake. Desktop Dungeons is one of my favorite games of all time, and it's so great to have a remastered version for its 10-year anniversary.

IF YOU ARE NEW TO DESKTOP DUNGEONS: This is a no-brainer recommendation. This game, while simple on the surface, is strategically deep and very unique - nothing else quite scratches the itch for me. There is a learning curve, but it's worth it!

IF YOU ARE FAMILIAR WITH THE GAME: First of all, you can import your old kingdom if you link your account, so no re-grinding! Second, while the game is mostly the same, there are a few very smart adjustments. The first thing you'll probably notice is the new dungeon layout that is better suited to widescreen resolutions. There are also tweaks to classes like Fighter and Berserker. And of course, there's the namesake Rewind feature.

Like me, you may be turned off by DD:R's UI at first. It is very, very different from the original. When you're used to seeing the entire dungeon at once, it feels jarring to start zoomed in. Instead of having the most important UI items clustered together on one side of the screen, they are spread out across the perimeter. But give it a chance - it grew on me, and I think it will grow on you too. It should definitely be an improvement for new players -  there are subtleties like enemies facing towards you when they will strike first, and combat prediction now extends to all status effects.

I have one major complaint: No custom keybindings. This is an accessibility issue, and it frankly is unacceptable that a remastered game released in 2023 lacks it. It should have been one of the core features. Hopefully it is implemented down the road.

Overall though, I'm so happy this game has gotten remastered. More than anything, I hope it brings in lots of new players and revitalizes the community!

The best whimsical roguelike puzzle game with updated graphics and a much floatier zeppelin. One of my favourite ever games. I've been playing it since the beta of the original game 10 years ago. Evil goats everywhere.

Disregard some of the negative reviews you see here; there has been a misinformation campaign pushed that the devs did not agree to nor advertise. 

IF you see negative reviews that complain about "being lied to", they were not. This is a revamp of the OG game. I own and have owned the OG game for quite a while, I playtested this game. Dev ran a promo that some devs do for people who own an OG copy of a game before a date (that's before today and before the OG one was put free for a promo). 

The smooth brained logic is "Well, reddit said that I get both games for free since the OG one is free I want my free copy of this updated game that took hundreds upon hundreds of dev hours to code because it's free because reddit said it's free."

No, this game is not free if you didn't own the OG one before the cut off date. It is on a discount, and for as chonky as the game is, the full price is worth it.

This says I only have .8 hours. That's false, I have far more across all iterations of the OG games elsewhere and playtested this one. 

What is this game? It's a roguelike puzzle-like that has dynamic elements which are more chaotic and does not have victory as an assurance with careful planning intermixed with a puzzle mode with set dungeons and set patterns that are totally mathematical and able to be beat.

If you played the OG one, but, for some reason don't own it on Steam, Rewind was built the way a remake/remaster should be done. It is 1:1 with the OG, while also adding stuff too, and the graphical upgrade is fantastic.

The game is set with a twisted sense of humor that, if you're one of the now endangered species of folk like I feign to be, and have that dwindling and more rare per day due to reddit and facebook and twatter,  that golden goose called wit, you'll probably enjoy that. Otherwise... IDK what to tell you.

Speaking of reddit. Just because reddit says it's so does not make it so.. I mean... ffs... the spirituality subreddit is taken over by "white light, nobody has an original self and all news is lies, there's not dire situations affecting the world and we're all the shchizophrenic universe trying to understand itself, so we don't have a reason to have authentic personalities or critical thinking because woo woo bs." Did reddit have a golden age? IDK, sifting through that mess is just about as bad as it was sifting through the septic tank that is facebook for a while, it's just getting waste... err waist... high and not ankle high, and people pounce on others with weak gacha's they've got to almost beg for someone to set up, with replies that're absolutely devoid of any intelligence whatsoever. Am I missing a good side of reddit? IDK, maybe I am, however, the point is... Dev would announce a promo like "Hey, get both games for free." here on Steam and on their discord. No such promo was ever promised, and anyone who gets a copy of this game for free did so because one promo was to give it free to people who bought the OG; Giving the OG game for free for a span of time was also a cool deal they have going on for a few days, damned generous to give both games away free to separate audiences. Neither of these promo's overlaps, and don't believe the BS that they do.

They're an indie team ffs, if you want to gripe about someone not giving you something for free, Ubisoft/EA/Blizzard have your number, and will happily give you many free games that come with an inbuilt casino that gets you addicted to pay for the free game.

Devs gotta eat, and, imo, these devs are being EXTREMELY generous by offering those two separate promo's at the same time on top of a launch discount. 

Yes, I did receive this game for free, no, I did not receive the OG one for free, which is why I got this one for free, I've owned the OG one for years on Steam. Also, no, just because I get a game for free that's paid, that does not inhibit me from being brutally honest and tearing into a game done bad, this game is genuinely a good game, and I thoroughly encourage you to at the very least try the demo if it's still available, or, if this is before the cut off date later on in the month, snag the OG one and try it out to see if you like it, if you do, then, this is worth the money spent.

Finally, this is the only game I've had an external sign on for that didn't wipe my saves between devices. This includes my OG save from my first kingdom. I was able to play it in browser, on the old laptop, then another laptop, also my phone when Elite Dangerous destroyed that other laptop, and this one, in the original version and the new rewind version.

Worth a try if you don't mind thinking out your moves.

Well, I goat to say, I'm really impressed with these creatures! They may be a bit bleat, but they're definitely not sheepish when it comes to being entertaining.

As for why they had to be goats, well, it's because they're the G.O.A.T. (Greatest Of All Time)! With their silly antics and playful personalities, they're sure to keep you laughing and feeling fawn-tastic all day long.

Plus, they're incredibly versatile - whether you need a trusty companion for a hike, a furry friend to snuggle up with, or even just a source of milk and cheese, these horned beauties have got you covered.

So if you're feeling a little ho-hum, why not add some goat-titude to your life? Trust me, it'll be a baa-rilliant decision.
I love sylas <3
You can pet the dog and you get rewarded for it 11/10

The actual game-play feels a bit mindless, compared to many other games in a similar category I would just not recommend this game. The environments while they look nice feel very empty in the actual play.

So the game is good, it's not worth $30 at all, it should be $15 or something. The game seems approximately 10-ish hours. I got this number based on the frequency of achievements every time I finished a mission (around 10 to 15 mission achievements). And the DLC is not worth it. Seriously, the Spells Pack is Riot Forge trying to get more money from the consumers, things like that should NEVER be locked behind your wallet.  

The gameplay so far (and based on other comments and videos i have seen) is a fair-paced rouge*LITE*. The combat area is similar to Wizard Of Legend (a better-priced game that uses magic quite well). If you are looking for the fast-paced movement of Hades, you will not find it here. BUT if you have played games like Wizard Of Legend, Binding Of Issac, and Dead Cells (Excluding the bizarre movement speed you can reach in Dead Cells) then you might like the pacing of this game. 

The combat can be clunky and monotonous if you ONLY button mash and you don't try to be creative in your attacks. Using the chains to follow up and (insert your attacks here) is one example of doing this. 
Despite only having an hour in as of writing this, I am fully aware that the gameplay will still be the same, as for the graphics and quality it is purely subjective.

The lack of voice acting should not be a reason to dislike the game. While it is true Riot Forge could have done more, it should not be the sole reason to dislike it. 

TLDR:

A great game made by Digital Sun (seriously Moonlighter is good and try out 11 Bit Studios games as well) and a very pleasant time. However, it shouldn't be priced so high for such a short game (keep in mind I hypothesize it to be 10 ish hours). Best to wait for a sale, but that is the choice of the publisher. Since it is Riot that published it, don't expect one anytime soon.

Pros:
Minecraft Legends boasts good graphics and a cel-shaded style reminiscent of Borderlands and Minecraft trailers.
The game has a well-built open world that's either procedurally generated or manually built brick by brick.
The game mechanics are fun and engaging, and the feature set is interesting, with players able to construct and control minions like golems, send allies to collect resources, and build structures in an Age of Empires style.

Cons:
The quests can be repetitive, such as defending villages and slaying mobs, leading to boredom.
The storyline is slow and uninspiring, which might not keep players engaged.
The price point of the game is a little high, considering its current features. However, it could be improved with future updates.
Overall, Minecraft Legends has some great aspects, including graphics, open world, game mechanics, and feature set. But, the game needs to work on its quest variety, storyline, and price to keep players engaged in the long run.

Sausage Bomber is apparently a popular mobile game that came out a while back and Dogfight is that developer's attempt to make a shmup spin-off of it. It's short and on the default difficulty, not particularly hard, but it does play well and has some neat features to encourage replayability.

You have 4 characters to choose from, though they are purely cosmetic in difference. Up to 4 player local-only co-op is supported, but you could also use Steam Remote Play to play online with others off a single copy. Every level has a star rating based on how well you play and the more stars you collect across all your saves, the more of the rather extensive weapon catalog you'll unlock. Some weapons are definitely notably better than others, but it gives you a lot of different playstyles to experiment with and it's nice that it doesn't have to be done off a single save slot.

Strangely, though Dogfight has a fairly robust scoring system, there are no leaderboards of any kind, offline or online. I'm not sure why they'd bother putting together a scoring system and then provide no way to track it.  There is an interesting speedrun system where a timer is attached to each save and you can have the game increase its speed every time you kill an enemy (and decrease when you get hit), up to 1.6x normal speed to encourage shorter playtimes. There are also local stats tracked for your speedruns, which makes the lack of score leaderboards even stranger. Still, it's neat to see a game embrace speedrunning in its core mechanics like this.

Honestly, the price for this is pretty steep given the content on offer, unless you want to play it multiple times through to get all the unlocks or compete for speedrunning times. It's not a bad shmup by any means and I enjoyed my time with it, but was surprised to see the price afterward.

One of Riots weakest aspects as a corporation/ game development company is the stories they write- i.e, they don't. At least, not anymore. For the past 5-6 champions, lore surrounding them has been pretty bare-bones.
When Sylas first came out, he actually had a really interesting story- however, Riot being Riot, did not elaborate on it at all. They also tried to both-sides the story a little bit (Demacia is very fascistic), which always rubbed me the wrong way. Sylas, while not necessarily a good guy, is definitely in the right in his story.

Mageseeker really adds a lot more to Sylas' character. This is the first time I've really seen or felt him being portrayed in a more sympathetic light- Sylas is clearly a broken man. He doesn't want to go into dungeons all that much, he seems to have a hard time making friends. While I'm still fairly early on in the game and I don't think the story is anything to take to the presses, I greatly appreciate that Sylas' character gets a bit more exploration in this.

The gameplay loop is... interesting. Initially, I did not expect the amount of upgrades that would be available, but the more mages you recruit into your camp, the more you can upgrade aspects of your character. There's honestly more depth in the system than I would have expected when I started the game. The combat is fun, if a little mindless. The ability to steal and use the magic of other mages is really cool, but its implementation is a little clunky, even with mouse+keyboard. Having to press shift+ right mouse while also hovering over the specific target can be tedious, especially in combat when there are so many enemies around.

The art is, I think, a bit of an acquired taste. In the over world, characters are sparsely detailed, but their silhouettes are very identifiable, so it's not like it's messy or confusing. Character art during dialogue looks a little awkward to me, but that could be because I'm used to Riots portraits. The actual environments are nice, but it does sometimes feel a little constrained in that corridors feel very narrow, and even battle arenas feel small at times (though they do vary them up quite a bit, which I appreciate). I imagine that, as I continue playing, I'll get to see a little more of how Digital Sun decided to depict Runterra- Demacia is, canonically, very large, and has a lot of interesting biomes you can play with (still hoping to see some petricite forests). 
I am a little confused as to why there's no voice acting in the game, as I would think it wouldn't be that difficult to get Sylas' voice actor given Riots notoriety, but that may have been a decision on Digital Suns part. The music feels very in-line with Leagues music in that its not very boisterous, but its still a good listen, and you do notice it if you pay attention.

Overall, I've enjoyed my time with the game thus far. Maybe my opinion will change as I play through, but I think Digital Sun is really good at beat-em-ups, so I can't imagine I'll dislike it all that much.

I was so mad i got Chat gtp to write me a review in the style of Siskel and Ebert. Its 100% accurate.

"Well, we just had the displeasure of experiencing what can only be described as a soulless and predatory excuse for a cart racer. This game lacks any of the charm, polish, or heart that we have come to expect from a Disney-branded product.

From the moment we launched the game, we were bombarded with predatory monetization tactics that left a bad taste in our mouths. It's clear that the developers were more interested in squeezing every penny out of their customers than creating a fun and engaging game.

But even if we look past the monetization, The game play is uninspired. A truly Middling experience.

It's truly disappointing to see such a beloved brand being tarnished by a game that clearly prioritizes profits over quality. We can't in good conscience recommend this game to anyone, and we hope that Disney takes a hard look at the developers they are partnering with in the future.

In short, this game is a cheap cash grab that fails to deliver on any level. We give it two thumbs down."

[h1] Review [/h1]

📜 [b]Intro[/b]
Deathchron is an action and platform game with an 8-bit style quite similar to the nes games with a limited color palette and music, like the games of that time Deathchron does not have a deep story so is simple and barely understandable is explain with a few images: you find a robot, you drive it, you kill enemies and you save the world.
There are 5 different levels and the selection of these is through a screen where the physical locations of these levels are shown and you select the desired level very similar to megaman but with the big difference that the levels are locked and you have to follow a linear order yes or yes, which makes this type of level selection screen meaningless, the game pays a lot of tribute to 8-bit games with a beautiful and well-detailed pixel style as well as the sound track but this last ends up being poorer because all the levels share the same song even in the fighting with bosses which takes away epicism since it is very tiring to listen to the same music all game.

🎮 [b]playable mechanics[/b]
The game is in 2D with classic gameplay of moving forward, jumping and shooting enemies, several enemies are capable of shooting so you constantly have to dodge enemy shots by jumping, the robot has a 3-state health bar which you can increase with upgrades from the menu by spending pieces that enemies drop and special orbs that reward you when you solve a special puzzle or kill a boss (currently the system is bugged so you can infinitely collect an orb if you collect it and then die), these upgrades in addition of life there are also special weapons, they have their own ammunition, the bad thing is that to reload a single bullet these special weapons you have to use a container [E] which are limited and also serves to restore your life so if you want to reload special weapons you can't heal yourself.
An added mechanic is the possibility for the child to get off the robot to go through small places or climb stairs to solve puzzles on occasions necessary to advance and on others for special items, the child's mobility is limited as well as his life ( which is reduced to 1), it is not highly recommended to get out of the robot often since the child can only jump one block so if you move away from the robot it is likely that you will not be able to return to it and you will end up stuck.
The level design is generally good, it feels entertaining and challenging, in addition to keeping elements typical of the games of that time, such as the typical water that is instakill, as well as the enemies that shoot at you while you jump, jumping into the water and having to start from the last save point.
Each level has a themed boss with the environment of the level, the visual design is magnificent but the playable one not so much since some of the bosses' attacks seem unavoidable especially the first boss.

💭 [b]Conclusion[/b]
The game is short and visually it is fantastic, it really looks like an 8-bit game from past times but with current gameplay as well as fluid control, but unfortunately it cannot be recommended for purchase in its current state, the game has many bugs such as getting stuck in certain places, that of the infinite improvement objects and worst of all, the possible corruption of the saved game in which it can take you to another more advanced level and with the corrupted level making it impossible to continue and having to start the game from the biginning. If these severe bugs are solved you can give it a try since the game is cheap and is entertaining.

I'm going to preface this review by saying that I actually like the game. 
I love the show Stargate, and this is the Stargatge game I've always wanted. 
I also plan to continue playing the game, but I wouldn't recommend it to anyone right now. I've run into quite a few bugs and I've only been playing for 2 hrs.
I have to create a new save every time I save the game, which isn't game breaking. Its just annoying.
My worker-bots keep being idle even when there is work to do and i have plenty of money (maybe there is a reason why they're not working that I'm not aware of?).
But the worst bug I've come across is my camera not panning. About every 10 minutes or so my camera will freeze and I'm unable to move around (I can still zoom in and out though). The only way to fix it is to log out of the game. 

The game is also lacking visually. All the rooms are very bland looking and there really Isn't any customization or decorating options. I know its suppose to look like a government facility, but it doesn't need to look THAT boring. 

Overall, it looks promising. But it is going to need a lot more content and some major bug fixes to be worth the price tag.

While I haven't played fighting games past a casual level, I am a huge rhythm game nerd and am having a blast playing this game.

I see a lot of reviews complaining about the lack of a vertical scrolling option, and I honestly do not think it should be added SOLELY on the basis of convenience. Hear me out.

I can play some of the hardest charts of Museca, Jubeat, Chunithm, Guitar Hero, Groove Coaster, Taiko, Crossbeats, Muse Dash, Osu!, and Osu!mania. I greatly enjoy but suck at Pop'n, SDVX, and PIU doubles. 

Why did I bother listing those? If you look them up, almost all of them have a different take on how a player hits notes. Some of them are super intuitive and can be learned quickly (for me, Jubeat), but some of them can take extra practice to learn even if you have an extensive rhythm gaming background (Taiko and SDVX). Different people pick up different games faster, even some of the "hard" games can be easy for some folks to learn.

In the same way, some fighting games are pretty intuitive in their controls (smash), while other games require a lot of learning and practice before you even remotely begin to feel like you're experiencing the intended gameplay (skullgirls).

I think it is entirely okay for God of Rock to come out with a new take on rhythm games in the form of a difficult 4-key horizontal lane. It just means you probably can't hit the ground running and be a pro. You actually have to take time to learn the controls, figure out what keybinds work for you, and above all else practice if you want to be decent. Just like a lot of the harder rhythm AND fighting games.

I generally think the game is challenging. If you're not used to reading streams and patterns, ESPECIALLY in a horizontal format like Taiko, this game will be really, really hard.

If it's purely an ACCESSIBILITY issue, as in no matter how much a person practices they can't physically read the notes coming in sideways, then yes by all means please add a vertical option if possible. Make the game accessible. But if it's just for the sake of convenience? I'm okay with this game taking me extra time to feel comfortable. The game doesn't need to be convenient and easy to learn, but it will limit the number of people willing to play (just look at other reviews lol). 

So I guess it's up to the devs to decide which matters more, a small audience of players willing to improve to be able to play, or a wider audience. I was looking for a challenging rhythm game, and that's exactly what I got, so I overall recommend it if you're looking for that.

[h1] Not recommending at the present time for a number of reasons, each explained below later. TLDR at the end.[/h1]

First, let's talk about the positives.

Gameplay is great. Short learning curve for basic mechanics (driving, items, etc.), and races are very exciting. I'm having fun in every single one. I've been playing single-player for my first couple of hours, but the bots are competitive, so you won't be disappointed if you want higher difficulty. 

There's plenty of modes, whether you want to play single-player or online. You start with a "starter circuit" that you need to progress on in order to unlock the other modes. If you want to race as Mickey, Donald or Goofy, you're in luck because you unlock those characters within the first hour or so.

Graphics and the overall look/feel of the game is good. Soundtrack lowkey slaps (remixes of classic Disney songs in electronic/club style) However the cars look extremely generic. Would have loved it if each of the characters drove in their own themed cars like Mario Kart but the liveries for the cars fit the characters well. 

Another thing I want to say is how blown away I was when they announced Figment as a character. As a fan of the Disney Parks and the lore/history surrounding the character, I can appreciate him coming into the limelight more. And if Figment was the first Parks related character that the devs announced (he IS in the Walt Disney World collection), I can bet that they're going to add more as the seasons come and go. (Hell, we even got our first Dreamfinder reference in YEARS, even if he's only a crew member. And I can appreciate seeing Orange Bird and Sonny Eclipse as well. Huge surprises.) The Figment announcement is what compelled me to buy the game in the first place.

Which brings me to the negatives; of which there are a few:

The amount of grinding one will have to do in order to obtain the characters/cosmetics/upgrades and whatnot will be long as hell. This is because this game is designed like a typical mobile/gatcha game. The amount of microtransactions here are overwhelming. No game should have FOUR in-game currencies. It will take me a LONG time to unlock Figment because he is the rarest character in the game, and the whole character shards thing being pegged to the rarity level makes it even worse. You also can't unlock the loot box that these shards are in unless you have 10,000 "season coins" that can mostly only be unlocked if you have the season/battle pass. (I will say that the standard founders pack gives you two credits towards your first two passes, but after that, it's money out of your pocket.) 

There's also no excuse for early access and the standard founders pack to be worth $30. Most people can wait until the game goes free-to-play later this year. It just isn't worth it for most people just to be able to unlock special skins and be a couple steps ahead of everyone else. I have heard that people aren't receiving refunds on their editions since it is technically DLC and cannot be returned. Really scummy thing to do. 

I also think the whole upgrading/crew experience is more complicated than it needs to be. I think many people will find it overwhelming. This also kinda plays into the microtransactions; if you want your car to go faster, drift better, etc. then you either grind for a long time or pay your way up.

Overall, for the average person, I would definitely wait until this goes free-to-play if you want to check this out. Early access isn't worth it, at least for me. But everyone is different. If you really like Disney characters and love kart racing, and simply can't wait a few months, then go ahead and get it. It really is a fun kart racer, but the obvious cash-grab elements and convoluted progression system stick out like a sore thumb. I hope Gamestop and Disney can get their act together on these fronts. 

[b]TLDR: The game is fun, graphics are good, and Figment is in it,  but the convoluted progression and microtransactions are overwhelming. Do NOT shoot for early access if you have any doubts about it, it's not worth it for most people. Wait for the game to go free-to-play. If any of the negatives significantly improve, I'll update the review accordingly, but in it's present state, the game needs some work.[/b]
very fun and chaotic

I don't think this is worth buying atm. You should wait until it exits early access. The racing feels great with a very big caveat being that you are forced to level up each racer, level up their star level and these require a variety of currencies to achieve. The multiplayer mode where everyone picks a character and you're on a level playing field is great. The game is fast and the items have multiple uses. Each character has a unique power up as well. I think the tracks are a joy to race on too. Lots of different paths or rails to grind which offer some strategy. It's just held back by the f2p monetization. It's just so egregious. 3 different currencies, currencies to level up each racer by franchise and type. Then you need to collect multiple of each racer to level up their star power... It just never ends. It's a shame because it is a fun game and I am enjoying it, but I wish I had known how deep the microtransactions went. Also it's a bit messed up that you get a free character unlock with early access but the game doesn't show you the character rarity until after you pick one. Meaning I got stuck with a less rare and easier to acquire character.

Great indie horror game!

You control a land drone from the 90's in a cave searching for body's/evidence on what is actually going on.

This game has great atmosphere and sound design!

Definitely worth the money!

Highly Recommend!!!!

Man, this is what indie games are all about.  Embracing the limitations and turning them into something artistically amazing.  

This is basically a walking simulator but in the form of investigative tapes and you control the state of the art drone (for the 90s).  The story is solid; while an overused subject, I liked this interpretation.  The graphics and display all work in favor of a found footage collection.  

This is a pure work of art.  This is why I play indie games.  This is also why I particularly like indie horror.  Expect a good 35-45 minutes.

Easy 9/10  BRAVO!! BRAVO!!!!

Bought the previous version when I randomly came across the promotion.  It's definitely more puzzle game than dungeon crawler.  I'm engaged in it a lot more than I expected to be.  Don't be like me and just skip all of the tutorials at first, they're well done and informative without wasting too much of your time explaining obvious nonsense.

One thing that isn't great is the quality of the display.  It's pretty clear that they didn't do a high resolution version of the UI as at 4K it looks soft and blurry as if it's just been crudely upscaled, so the presentation isn't great.  Could have easily jazzed up the graphics in general by a LOT while still running fine on potato PCs.

I hecking LOVE Desktop Dungeons.

I think I've actually been playing this game since its inception, I was probably in middleschool when I found this game. I remember when this game looked absolutely horrible and I still played it many weekends as a kid. It's been pretty neat watching the game evolve over the years. I wonder if I found it on gamemaker studios or just from googling roguelike rpgs.

But this is a pretty good roguelike puzzle rpg. It starts off fairly simple, but very quickly the game starts to get very difficult and you have to start to learn how to push every mechanic at your disposal to its absolute limit. Sometimes you might find a very powerful combo or exact counter to a level instead. You'll even start this game thinking a few race class combos are best but then you'll come across a mechanic that requires completely different types of builds. It stays fresh pretty well and there's a lot of challenge to try to overcome.
You can play a single game very quickly, if you have a lunch break you can play a round of this and move on easily.

I normally don't review games negatively but this one was a disappointment. I have been pretty excited to buy this and was really trying to give it some hope but at the end of the first day I am just sitting here pretty happy to be done playing it. Personally it is not frustrating but I was just super bored and I have played some pretty long RTS matches. Nothing happens for most of the match, it feels like its a stale mate up until its gone so long that people loose focus about defense. It takes already a long time to get into a match and I dont feel like I sit here wondering what I could of done better or what I want to change about my strategy for the next match. I absolutely dont think the multiplayer mode has longevity, I feel like the audience this game is probably going to attract does not have a deep sense for strategy for this type of game, nothing against them but it is already apparent to me that most of my teammates do not even understand what is going on. I know it is day one but its so bad that I cant hope for it to get much better. I have been the only one building defenses and when it comes to attacking everything feels week except the redstone launcher. I think this game is going to die out pretty quick so if you bought it I would try to get a refund if it is not too late. Wait for a sale to get the story mode, I personally can wait for that if I am still interested in giving a second chance. I hope I am wrong and this game makes some big changes but I am pretty doubtful as of right not. I am currently confused how Mojang let something like this on the market, they had to of seen some of these major flaws before launching. Luckily I stopped just in time for a refund.

I love minecraft, but this game has been a huge letdown on release in terms of the versus mode (pvp). The singleplayer is meh, I don't really play single player games (I only played some of it), so I won't touch on that. 

- The inability to conduct Teamwork
In many of the promotional content for this game, they really talk about the teamwork as being a main aspect of the game, yet there is no text chat nor voice chat. In addition, it is extremely difficult to play with friends in versus mode. You cannot queue with friends unless its a private match. You have to host or join a public game where you cannot even change teams to play on your friend's team. It seems the dev team said, "this game is fun on lan, lets release it". 

- No reason to play pvp except momentary fun
In comparison to other pvp competitive multiplayer games, this game fails to even come close to caring about the pvp mode. No leaderboards, no rewards, no nothing for winning. If you want to make a competition gamemode, at least capitalize on it by adding more fun things to it.

I like this game but, at this price, there needs to be more effort. I'm sure there are more cons to talk about but these two are the most important to me.

Well, it runs fairly smoothly. There's absolutely nothing to it though and if these guys are coding students, I don't know who is teaching them but they seem to have missed the bit where they create a worthwhile Hack and Slash game. These kids could be leaving university with a steady income if they'd just put a bit more game in their game. I would like to see a sequel with a bit more ultrawide aspect ratios support, some information about the abilities, lift all the good features from Hack and Slash (and Hades is NOT a stand out of the genre btw - it's simply one of the least bad ones that's still going), zoom out about 500% because this is to Hades as Duplo is to Lego at the moment. The game has 3 enemy types which is incredibly boring and there's no information about the levels that are coming etc etc etc.

I've no idea what they were learning from this - the only thing I can guess is that perhaps it's about the code in the background? It wasn't lagging even running at speed so maybe they created a hyper efficient code base in comparison to Hades which can really lag when it's got a lot of stuff on screen. Who knows?

Curse of the Corsair II please. Lets see what you can do when you try and make money, which should obviously be what students should be doing with these projects.
